description: What a wonderful experience and place to have a rehearsal dinner for my son's wedding party. We had a party of 12 center next to the roaring fire place. Chef Art was very attentive to organizing the dinner, he emailed and called me several times to confirm the menu. Chef Art gave me several choices for the main course (which was very reasonable). Started with a mixed green salad with champagne dressing topped with spiced pecans and crumbled blue cheese, everyone finished their salad. The main course was a choice of Roasted Chicken, Filet of Salmon or Beef Tenderloin which included asparagus, spring vegetables & fingerling potatoes. Everyone raved how delicious and tender the meal was. Once we were all stuffed, out came a very decadent dessert, Chocolate Mousse cake with Kahlua Creme Fraiche, very rich and delicious.  I can't thank Chef Art and his staff enough for the wonderful experience and the exceptional meal we all enjoyed. I would highly recommend the restaurant for weddings, parties or for a meal before the theater, it won't disappoint you.
author: Sandy M.

description:
They need to do some updating with information.

The times on Yelp and google are wrong, they are open for lunch although the listings do not reflect this.

Also, they lunch menu is limited, and when we went there on a Saturday before a symphony matinee performance, things ended up a lot more limited.

They offer three appetizers/starters, one of which was the reason we choose to go there, and the day we were there all there were unavailable. I understand running out of one item, but to have all 3 unavailable at the start of lunch is a bit absurd.

One of the pasta dishes was also not available, meaning almost a 1/4 of the lunch menu was not available. And one of the items, the crab melt, was not served the way it is listed on the menu. 

The only things saving this review from being less stars is that the food we had was excellent. The BLT was delicious, the bread soft, and good fillings to bread ratio.

The Crab Melt was also very good, the jalapeno slaw was spicy, but not overwhelmingly so, and complimented everything else.

The Serving sizes were very large, service was decent.

We just wish they would update information, have a real menu and have all of the food thy say is on the menu.
author: Sean A.

description:
It's not exactly the most cozy spot: south of market street is a little sketchy these days with all the homeless.
The city seems to be cleaning up the area, however, it still remains a problem.

Staying in the Whitcomb Hotel with this restaurant on the premises.   A fitting bar-restaurant with equally as old furniture as the hotel.

Didn't feel like heading out so went to the restaurant to have something to eat. 

Their appetizer Caesar salad is actually pretty tasty and for $11 it's a good size and more than enough as a meal.

Service is good, it also fits the restaurant. 

Will go back when staying here again. 
More for the salad than the dining experience and underwhelm atmosphere.
author: Joy S.

description:
Friends took me here for a birthday lunch.  It was my second time eating at this place.  Nice atmosphere very classy.  The menu is a bit limited.  First visit was much better then second.  Ordered a sandwich with avocado.  No avocado unfortunately I realize this halfway through.  Friend ordered truffle fries got regular fries.  I said something to the waiter and instead of apologizing he offered to get me a plate of avocado but said nothing about getting my friend the correct fries    Is it just me or isn't our waiter supposed to check the orders before they deliver them to your table?  For an upscale place with a fairly high prices I would think there be better service.  We ordered a dessert to share and he did put a candle in it for my birthday.  In my opinion that should've been free because of the mess up with our lunches.  

Update... 5/9/18:   The place is terrible.  We had a reservation.  We were seated only to be told there was no bartender and a couple things were not available on menu. So no drinks and well the place was empty so that told us what was up.  We left and went across the street to Sam's American Grill which was fabulous.  Not coming back!
author: Lori F.

description: This place is awful. They have no hours posted so nobody is aware until they get here it doesn't open until 5 pm - on Saturdays at least. My main complaint: they have a separate "bar menu" and "restaurant menu" - mind you the bar is INSIDE the restaurant, but if you want something off the "bar menu" then you can only sit in the "bar area." The bar menu and appetizer menu are almost exactly the same, except the bar menu has a hamburger option with truffle fries. I attempted to order this in the restaurant and the waitress tells me "that's for the bar, we can't because people may come in and see you eating it and it's not on the menu." Here's a wild idea: PUT IT ON THE MENU THEN! The wine was mediocre at best and their food is far from the best on the street. My suggestion, go somewhere else. Preferably somewhere the menu is the same no matter where you're sitting.
author: Kai R.

description:
This is a great pre Orpheum place to eat.  We had the crab cake an calamari for appetizers. Quite good. Portion size was decent. 

We also split the steak which was huge. With mashed potatoes and broccoliini. Really good.
author: Frank T.

description:
An exceptionally average establishment.  The staff are helpful and friendly, the location is very convenient if you are going to one of the local theaters, but there is nothing outstanding about it.

Our meals were of a reasonable size, but did not stand out as anything special, especially considering the cost of each plate. We didn't sample anything from the bar and from other reviews that may be the highlite of the establishment.

The bathrooms are a bother. They are situated in the common entryway surrounded by the street, Florinda's, Starbucks, and the hotel desk. You have to get a card-key to get in and they seem to be watched by folks who want to get in (Starbucks customers, transients, etc).  I don't want to be the police for someone's bathroom and it's uncomfortable to deal with "hold the door" or "let me in". The first time I used the room a guy surfed in right after me (was I supposed to slam the door in his face?) and when I exited there was a security guard giving me the stink eye.
author: Sean S.

description:
I went here with 3 friends. It was walking distance from the library and City Hall. We were seated right away since they just opened and there was no one there. Our waiter was nice and let us looked at the menu before hovering. The decor was pretty classy and nice. 

After we ordered our food, the soups came first, we had to ask for bread. I thought bread is supposed to come without asking? I was a little disappointed that service was kinda Meh. There weren't anyone there except our table. Service should be exceptionally fantastic! SHOULD. 

Food finally came, like they went out to the ocean and caught the mussels, clams, and salmon. Yep, it took a long time. I would understand if they were super busy, but they weren't!!!

I had a clam chowder and a caprese salad. Chowder had shells, milky and brownish from the bacon I later found out. I kept thinking my filling came out since I had a crunch sounding a few times!!!!

Overall, it was OK. Not sure I'll come back.
author: Eugenia W.

description: Just ate here last night with the hubby and baby! Sat in the bar/lounge area. Our bartender cessy was amazing! Awesome service! Food was amazing!! An dim not just saying that. We ordered the bruschetta, muscles, and the creole pepper steak. All of it was phenomenal!!! Very satisfied. Definitely would recommend
author: Christy M.

description:
Cozy venue for a pre-show dinner. The restaurant is located in Hotel Whitcomb's lobby. Orpheum theatre is just across the street. If you drive past the hotel make a right turn on the next street and you'll find civic center parking on your left and a private parking on your right ($20), straight ahead is valet parking ($40 plus tax). We had no idea that the $20 parking was the same one we made parking reservations for Jersey Boys (online it was Parking Panda for $40). It was Superbowl weekend in SF and traffic was a bit tight in the city. Left Santa Clara at 3pm & arrived at the parking site at 4:15. The rest of our group arrived later and had no problems with parking at all. Restrooms in the lobby were secured and had to be opened by an attendant. 

We made reservations for 5:30pm and were seated as soon as a table for 8 was ready, took about 5 minutes. We ordered the potato bacon soup. It was creamy & full of flavor, small cuts of bacon & potato added some texture. We cleaned up the bowls! The other couples had the salad & the garden flatbread. Not a morsel was left on the plate. Later on, the entrees arrived. My steak was med rare & was juicy. The salmon was not dry & the lamb chops were delicious! For dessert, I enjoyed every bite of the lemon dome. A good balance of sweet & tart together. 

We told the waiter that we had a 8pm show at Orpheum & we took quite a bit of time to just sit & chill. I found our table to be the most entertaining with lots of laughs. We left at 7:15 and did not feel hurried by the waiter at all. Service was prompt, food was delicious & company was great. Woyld love to come back here.
author: Ammie A.

description:
"Phantom" is playing at the Orpheum again, so they shouldn't have any problem filling this place up before the curtain. It must be a blue-hair magnet. How else would they justify such a bland menu? I think the most exotic thing they served was bruschetta. I'm not sure what motivated me to enter the Hotel Whitcomb to try this place except that it was open at around 9:30PM when I finally got around to eating dinner after a long day at work. It looked like they already closed up the dining room, but the bar was still open. There was an older woman trying to seduce the bartender. Less Mrs. Robinson, more like a drunken Nancy Grace.

I had to order from their bar menu which surprisingly featured a couple of their entrees (photo: http://bit.ly/1i6VRIj). I went for the $22 Petaluma Herb Chicken with Beurre Blanc, Fingerling Potatoes and Baby Vegetables (photo: http://bit.ly/1ISyqHL) because I felt like a real dinner even though it meant overhearing Nancy discuss her gymnastic flexibility with the bartender. There was definitely a wedding banquet style to the plate presentation, but that didn't prevent it from being fairly tasty for a piece of poultry. I doubt I'll make a habit of coming here since I'm not into Andrew Lloyd Webber bombast, but maybe Nancy will start looking good to me.
 
FOOD - 3 stars...a meal you'd find in Business Class, for better or worse 
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...dated hotel motif
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...the bartender was attentive...but don't encourage Nancy
TOTAL - 3 stars...Phantom of the Poultry
author: Ed U.

description: Went before a show at the shn and I am sure they knew. Everything was brought out quickly and It was all great. Well everything except the price. A bit pricey imo but what can you expect in the city where you can find $30 grilled cheese sandwiches. Great location if going to a show. Good food. Good service.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Market Street Grill is conveniently located near the Orpheum Theatre and inside Hotel Whitcomb. We started with the crab cake appetizer. That was the highlight of Market Street Grill. Although, it was only one piece...it was very thick and whetted our appetites for our steak entrée. It was paired with an avocado relish that complimented it so well.
Next, I had the Filet Mignon which I requested for it to be cooked Medium and instead got Well Done. The server said she can have it re-done, but we were on a time limit so I just ate it anyways. It was OK... but what I liked mostly about that dish is the onion rings on the top that added a nice crunch with my steak. My husband had the Angus Steak which was prepared Medium Rare when he asked for Medium Well. That too was OK.

The place is dimly lit and has a bar. Also, service was attentive and quick. They serve complimentary bread and butter.
author: Sharon Q.

description: Came in before seeing Hamilton.  Restaurant is open and they were serving drinks from the bar.  However, unless you were eating you couldn't get a drink.  That's odd...you will turn away people who want to get a drink...when you have people serving drinks...great business model.
author: Jenny T.

description:
DH and I came to the city for dinner and a show and decided on Market Street Grill based on its proximity to the Orpheum. 

We made reservations through opentable, 5:15p was the latest they had available where we could eat and still make our 8p. 

We were greeted by the hostess and the matradee and both were pleasant. DH and I had our choice of tables and sat near the window to take in the pre-show of people watching, which is always fun in the city. 

Our waiter came over right away, as a matter of fact DH had left to use the facilities "another story", I took it upon myself to order a bottle of Pinot Noir.

The wine arrived and was delicious, we ordered the Bruschetta appetizer at the recommendation of our waiter and it arrived promptly. We ordered our entrées, me the halibut and DH the Salmon. Not 2 minutes after the appetizer was cleared the entree was presented.  Our waiter also filled or wine glasses even though they had no less than 5oz in them already. How odd I thought?

By this time it was around 6p, 45 minuted into dinner and plates were cleared wine was poured and the remaining tables were filled. I was feeling pressured to turn the table. We were asked about dessert and ordered one to share and two expressos.  

Mind you we were still drinking our wine, glasses quite full when dessert arrived and the expresso. 

How awkward....Now I have wine and expresso, what is a girl to do?! 

I take another gulp of wine, dig into the dessert, the bill arrives, oh my god I have to be quick! Expresso time, more dessert, pay the bill, go go go!!

For a $100+ meal I hate to feel rushed, especially when we are not lingering, the food was decent, but 3 stars is all I can allow for that marathon meal.
author: Lorri D.

description:
Convenient location that is tucked right in with the hotel!

Great for a lounge stop since it is close to the Orpheum theatre!

They have a piano, bar and the good 'ole American food, such as wings, burgers, fries and so forth!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Just trying to grab a cocktail before the Orpheum theater. Perfect location across the street; unfortunately you can not get waited on. We stood at the bar for 15 minutes and the bartender did not even acknowledge us. We were dressed up and out on a date. We were so disappointed. The bartender should have at least acknowledged us and said I will be right with you but instead she was bussing dishes off the bar. She did not have the skills to multi-task. What a shame we got a bad impression and did not even get a chance to try the food or drink. We walked out and no one cared!
author: Lisa B.

description: I was looking for a place for my family to have dinner before seeing a show at the Orpheum, but I was hesitant after reading some of the negative reviews here. I decided to go ahead and make a reservation anyway and I'm glad to report that we had a good meal, with good service too. I didn't go in expecting a high-end, farm-to-table experience that would blow my mind. This place is more old school supper club. The decor is a combination of old world charm and a bit musty. The menu is traditional steak-chicken-pasta and fairly no frills. It did what it does suitably well and we all left satisfied.
author: Cheryl S.

description: Went to the Orpheum for a show and grabbed a bite to eat beforehand. They flexed to quickly give us a table for six, which they were holding for a reservation that was in 90 minutes -- we agreed to be out before then. Mixed drinks were a little weak, but the food was generally very good. The seafood was especially impressive -- incredibly fresh and perfectly cooked -- calamari, clam chowder, and salmon were all fantastic. Only miss on the food was the carrot soup. Delicious desserts. Friendly and unpretentious service, reasonably priced considering the location. Will go back if opportunity presents itself!
author: Zachary R.

description:
Yes, this is another one of those 'if I could give zero stars I would' reviews.   It's pretty obvious that the only reason they are in business is because they have a location across the street from the Orpheum and nothing else is within two blocks.  

I sat at the bar to get a drink while waiting for a friend to arrive at Civic Center Bart.   It took about ten minutes for the bartender to even make eye contact with me, even though there were only two other people at the bar.    While waiting I saw  him barely go through the motions, spilling half the drinks he made, throwing equipment around etc.   He was either 1) high 2) preternaturally insolent 3) lazy as hell....most likely all of the above.

I ordered a Makers Mark Manhattan and saw him make it with some other bourbon.  At that point I was so over it I just said nothing.   

Horrible experience, and while sitting at the bar I could tell it was the same for everyone.   Go only if you are desperate!
author: Brian F.

description:
My theater companion and I selected this restaurant because it was on OpenTable, because it was diagonally across the street, and because we got last-minute tickets to see Book of Mormon at the Orpheum and didn't want to travel too far. It was telling, as soon as we sat down, and I pulled up yelp, that the keywords messed mentioned we're about the Orpheum, the proximity, the theater, the shows.

I should have them put two into together and realized that this was not a subtle clue about the restaurant.

The dining room itself was shabby. That's the only word I can think of to really describe it. Multiple lightbulbs were browned out or completely burned out throughout the dining room. Stains on the carpet. The wood on the chairs was chipped and faded. It reminded me of the hole in the wall diners you find in Santa Cruz, except this was in the heart of downtown San Francisco. I honestly expected a bit more.

Our server was average. Not slow coming up fast. Not personable, not rude. Attempted to engage with her about the menu, didn't really get much feedback other than her saying the truffle fries were superior to the sweet potato fries. But I sort of had to pull that out of her. We went ahead and ordered.

My friend ordered the clam chowder, and said it was nothing special. I ordered a expensive negroni cocktail that was mostly ice. My friends chicken came and he said it was a bit dry. My chicken pesto sandwich came, and there was so much bread that that's all it tasted. Which would have been fine if it was spectacular bread. It wasn't.

The check for the two of us for lunch came to over $65. I've had far better branches for two in much nicer restaurants with far friendlier servers. For $30. I'm planning to go with a friend to see Book of Mormon again next Saturday, and I'm not joking, I think we're going across the street to Burger King to grab a Whopper. Okay, I am getting, will probably just hop on the Muni and go to Kitchen Story or something. But yeah, quite disappointing.
author: Sean B.

description: Completely disappointed.  I came in seeking a glass of wine and dinner after work.  I ordered a burger, which the menu stated was $15.  I did not add anything on to it, and expected to pay what the menu reflected, plus tax and tip.  I ended up getting charged an extra $4.50 for mushroom, avocado and tomato. I did not even eat the mushrooms, and never asked to add anything on, nor would I have!  When I saw the bill and inquired about the extra charges for additions I did not order, the rude bartender/server simply walked away.  I am kicking myself for leaving a tip at all as I can assure you Mr. D. Smith did NOT "insure proper service."
author: Charlotte K.

description: This place is so bad it's hard to find the words, service, food, decor, awful. The only reason this place is still in business is its proximity to the Orpheum theater and the fact there is nothing else within a safe walk. No excuse for how dreadful it is however.
author: Barbara F.

description: The Market Street Grill is a quiet restaurant located in legendary Whitcomb hotel. They have a very intimate interior with a low-key vibe and their dinner menu had a variety of delicious entrées. I ordered their short rib, which was sumptuous. The meat was fork tender and easily pulled apart and paired perfectly with the mashed potatoes and vegetables. The hefty portion was filling and left no room for dessert - but then again, I had enough of their complimentary baguette which was also really good.
author: Jonnathan B.

description: Food is good, service is good. It's near the Orpheus theatre. Yes the food isn't avant garde but it's made well. Prices are fair. The only complaint is we tried to get reservations before a show and only one available was at 5:45pm. We were hoping to get a 6:30pm reservation but was told it wasn't available. We took the 5:45pm reservation and when we left at 7:15pm we noticed the restaurant was still fairly empty. Confused me as why we couldn't get a 6:30pm seating.
author: Raymond L.

description: We always come here before theatre at the Orpheum. They do a great lunch and get us through in time for the matinee. Love the crab sandwich. Salads are great too. Sweet potato fries, yum. Cozy, feels like old time San Francisco with a fireplace, nice linens.
author: Kate B.

description:
Stopped in here for a drink and a bite to eat before the theater. The restaurant was closed (on a Sunday???) but bar bites were available.

The drinks were perfect (hence the star) and the bartender made the second round a little bit stronger indicating the experience of the bartender.

Had chicken quesadillas but they were nothing to write home about but expectations were low to begin with so we were not disappointed. 

I asked for the bill and bartender calculated on a adding machine so I didn't think there was a possibility for an error. After I checked the items, I was really surprised to see the total sum for two drinks and a couple of orders of quesadillas, but we were in a rush so I didn't bother to question the bill. I even gave him a generous tip because the drinks were good.

After I got home, I examined the bar tab closer and discovered that the bartender added an extra $8 to the total. Boy, was I disappointed. I thought I found another convenient watering hole but all I found was a rip-off joint.
author: Ed D.

description:
I don't think this restaurant is prepared for busy theater nights. We walked in and got a seat in the bar area, but no one came to take our drink order for 15 minutes. We got up and decided to go straight to the bar to get some service and there was one bartender working the whole joint.

Asked a waiter passing by if anyone was was going to take food orders in the bar seating area. He threw up his hands and rudely responded "Nope I am too busy". We continued to wait at the table in the bar until we gave up and I went nextdoor and got Starbucks sandwiches and brought them back into the restaurant and we ate them while we finished our drinks. Everyone seemed to be running around with their head cut off and I will never return, there are better places in the area.
author: Rosemary L.

description:
Came here because we couldn't get a reservation anywhere else close by. Worst clam chowder I've ever had and I'm no  connoisseur. Read other reviews that raved about it...but those were from many years ago. They may have started watering it down (to save money? Fffff...). ***And they have the audacity to charge $10 for a bowl of runny-ass clam soup.*** 

Caesar salad was standard (tasted like what you'd expect) but don't bother adding chicken for $4. Boiled and completely bland. 

French dip was flavorful but the sweet potato fries on the side came soggy. 

Mushroom ravioli was good. Get that.

Very hit and miss here; definitely not coming back. Good food? There are way better choices elsewhere...just plan ahead. Good value? A big emphatic NOOOOO.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Have stopped here many many times for dinner and drinks before attending the Orpheum. Over the years there have been a couple of forgivable bad experiences. 
Tonight's visit was a deal breaker. I'll never go back!! I'm assuming it's under new management/ownership. Horrible service is an understatement, mistakes made on the order, slower than slow:
 Accusing the four of us of making the mistakes, then accusing the kitchen of the mistakes.. How can it be the kitchens fault when we ordered chicken, and you delivered salmon? Do you not know the difference between the two? Never following up with a new glass of the wine that I ordered? Filling the water glasses, and delivering cold stale bread AFTER the starter was served? Which took twenty minutes.. Responding to our request for the check (because we were now late and had to get to the theatre, which we explained) by wandering around for fifteen minutes, then coming back to our table to ask if we wanted dessert...? Which we insisted NO, just the check.. Ten minutes later coming back to our table to ask if we wanted coffee... I swear to god they're lucky we didn't just bail, God knows they wouldn't have noticed for twenty minutes... 
On top of all of this, the ravioli was obviously frozen/pre packaged. The chicken was way over seasoned, the potato fingerlings had obviously sat heated for hours, the trout had the obvious signs of freezer burn. The wines by the glass are some of the lowest quality available, and don't ever expect the right one, or a refill, because it just won't happen.
Oh yeah, the bill finally came and they charged us for the salmon anyway, smfh! We should have told them how much they owed us for making us late, and walked out!

In summary, worst quality food, complete lack of customer care, not worth the frustration to even try!
author: Rick B.

description:
We had a party of 4 for dinner today. Everyone enjoyed their food. I though the seared ahi tuna with sauce and sesame seeds I had was the best. My wife asked for the ahi tuna apetiser with out any sauce.
The waitress brought exactly what my wife asked for
author: Ted M.

description: Just went in their today... Hostess said they were full and asked for our room number. Said she would call us as soon as they were available. Well I'm glad I took it upon myself to order MS SAIGON for delivery instead! No wonder I see bad reviews of this place...
author: Emil H.

description:
I rarely write reviews but this was an amazingly bad experience. Walk in, looks like a pretty high class place inside a classy hotel. That's when things went bad. I believe from the reviews there has been a change of ownership for the worst. I had a New York strip, medium rare, but I guess they figured well done was a better choice. It came with gravy like you would get at Thanksgiving. I felt like asking for "cowboy Joe" to bring me some good ol' A1 sauce.

We then paid our bill on two separate cards and it seems that was too much as they ran the same card twice! The mistake wasn't noticed until long after.

We were looking for a place near the Orpheum when we go to see plays... We'll keep looking.

The hamburgers looked good. In fact, my New York strip kinda looked like a hamburger.
author: The D.

description:
We stopped here for lunch before seeing The Book of Mormon at the Orpheum Theater.  This was right around the corner from parking and across the street from the Theater which made it super convenient. 

They asked if we had reservations but we didn't need them. We were seated immediately and able to order drinks as we took our seats.  

The staff was friendly. Prices $16 to $25 for lunch. Beautiful sit down restaurant.  Salads, soup, burger, French dip, chicken, chowder.... And more. They have a beautiful bar as well. 

You need a card key for the restroom which is in the lobby of the Whitcomb hotel. The restaurant is in the hotel but right on the street. 

We had the burger and the French dip. Big portion sizes and great tasting. You have a lot of choices for sides. We liked the onion rings and sweet potato fries. Would have given five stars but I'm conservative with those.
author: Clarity B.

description:
I needed a restaurant close to the Orpheum for dinner before the show. Also, it was for my wife's birthday. I was pleasantly surprised upon arrive. The restaurant has a stately, established feel...like you've found a San Francisco gem. The bartender made excellent drinks. The menu has a great selection. We all found excellent choices and the prices are good.

My definitely "go to" restaurant for the theatre nights.
author: Frank T.

description: We were headed to see Wicked at the Orpheum and stopped in here to have lunch before the show.  Service was not very friendly, but was fast and the food was good.  We had the French dip sandwich and the cheeseburger, both of which were delicious!  Highly recommend the sweet potato fries.  Burgers were $17 which is to be expected in the area.  Food quality was great and we will definitely be back!
author: Alexis A.

description: The worse food and service I've ever had. The service was horrible. It seemed the waiter was too tired to even get our order. Whatever we asked they were out of it. Will never eat here. Two dinner cost $80 and so unbelievably bad!!!
author: Sara P.

description:
Decided to give the restaurant in the hotel a try on our first night here. We were greeted right away by what we assume was the host who had someone's dinner in hand, he handed menus, told to pick any table we wanted and make ourselves at home, so that he could deliver what he was holding--ok not the best first impression.  Water was filled right away and after a moment bread was delivered to the table, problem was we didn't have plates--one of my friends actually had to get up and ask for plates.  We then watched and heard the host drop a check off at the table behind us and when the woman at the table went to take it, the host continued to hand it to the man at the table saying "the gentleman always gets the check". Everyone at the table was stunned. 

And then it got even better...we ordered our food. Two of our dishes were delivered to the table, it was then that the waiter told the third party at our table that the kitchen couldn't make his food and this was after almost 40 minutes. Are you kidding me??!!
And we found out that the host was actually the manager...

Horrible service. However I will say that the food that we did have was good.
author: Shannon L.

description: First time visit here was fantastic! Our bartender was outstanding  made great drinks and was so friendly I believe her name was Christy.  We will definitely be back again had a great time.  I would recommend this bar and the food was very good too!  We will make sure Christy is working before we head in again she is such a delight!
author: Debbie F.

description: Found this restaurant from Yelp, it's proximity to the Orpheum the main reason.  We attended the performance of Wicked with our girl scout troop and needed a place for dinner in advance.  Although the prices were higher than I had hoped, the service and food were good. The restaurant accommodated the 5 children with us with a choice of hamburger or spaghetti which was perfect for them. If attending a show at the Orpheum this is a good place to eat before.
author: Lisa S.

description:
I wish I could give the place two and a half stars, but I'll round it up to three. The first thing that I noticed when I walked in is how dark the entire space is, even natural light and floor to ceiling windows couldn't lighten the place enough during lunch time. Dark forest green gold and red(?) not s food color scheme for a dining room in my opinion, nonetheless it was dark. 
The service was lackluster, my mom and I went in for lunch and were greeted by a hostess whom I presume was also the manager. There were two other small tables occupied. This is the part that made me knock off two stars, the service or lack thereof. Our waiter (older Asian man) didn't introduce himself, offer water or the complimentary bread the other tables had. Although there literally was almost no one in the restaurant. He took our order and didn't offer drinks I had to stop him and add our drink order. He was very attentive to the other tables, and to be honest I think we didn't receive good service because of how we were dressed( in jeans) while the other patrons were having work lunch meals. Maybe he assumed we wouldn't tip well enough ? We ripped accordingly to the service we received.
The food was nothing special, not worth 16$ per sandwich if you ask me. The soda was borderline flat. We both had the pesto chicken sandwich and it was okay, the French fries were over salted . 
Overall I wouldn't venture this place again, not even if the meal was free.
author: Stephany R.

description: Not impressed. I ordered the ribeye and my husband got the grilled chicken. The ribeye has a weird fishy taste with too much pepper and not enough salt. The potatoes and dry and not great at all. My husbands' chicken was very fatty but the meat itself was pretty good. The restaurant itself is great! Great atmosphere and history in the building. Probably won't come back though.
author: Kaylin M.

description:
I first found this restaurant when I was looking for a place for dinner before going for a show at Orpheum Theatre.   I was pleasantly surprised  by this find.  The restaurant have an old world field (old world in my perspective :-) ).  The menu have a great selection to please every palate, even my picky vegan friends and the prices are decent.

Was at  the  restaurant again last Wed for dinner before the show with a group of 5.  The waiter asked if we were going for the show.  We got busy chatting and forgot to order.  He came over to remind us to place orders so we can make it to the show on time.  The serving were generous size.  I ordered the lamb chops.  Great flavor and cooked perfectly.   I am not into Americana food as I  think it is too heavy, however I enjoyed the food here.   My definitely "go to" restaurant for the theatre nights.
author: Ayn K.

description: My first impression of this establishment was that it must be a great place to eat because I saw a large amount of diners. I now feel that it's popular only because of its close proximity to the Orpheum Theater. The service was slow even though our waiter was pleasant enough. My friend and I each ordered the Orange and Pear Salad with grilled chicken. What we received was mostly mixed greens and chicken. There was a skimpy....and I do mean SKIMPY....serving of pecans, pear and oranges. One of the orders had Gorgonzola, the other one did not. What made my dining experience even worse was that my order had a few orange seeds! What a big disappointment. It may not be fair to make this judgment based on just one visit but because it was such a pricey disappointment for me I doubt if I will return.
author: Aleece C.

description:
I was invited to eat dinner by one of the hotel guests at the Whitcomb Hotel, where this restaurant resides, and I had a great experience. The customer service was outstanding, the servers treated us well and the bar staff accommodated every request. This is one of those places where you can tell the management cares about their patrons and their guests, and takes extra steps to make sure they give a positive experience every every day. Simply put, a rarity, and a true gem. I enjoyed the food and beer, too.

Now, I need to stay here the next time I visit San Francisco.
author: Erik N.

description:
I was looking for something close to the theatre at the last minute.  We had a party of 8 and most of what I could find in the area seemed to close to early for us.  I called to make a reservation and was told that they probably wouldn't be able to take such a large group until I said I wanted it at 5.  No problem.  We got there and they put us at a long table and the room was very nice.  They didn't tell us that the table was made up of three small ones put together so there were ledges between them.  This caused someone to spill their drink all over themselves and the table. 

The service was horrible!  It took so long for someone to come to our table my mother in law and sister in law went to the bar to order drinks, and was told that they couldn't order them there and take them back to our table.  They had to order them at the table.  WHAT?!

When my daughter ordered Sangria, the waiter looked at her like she was speaking German and then was told that they couldn't make it.  This wat a full service bar.

We wanted to split the check because there were 8 of us, and everyone was responsible for themselves.  The waiter said remind me when I bring the total and I'll split it out.  When it came time to that we started going over what everyone had and this seemed to be more then his brain could handle.  Thank god we had someone who runs a restaurant with us.  She took over and got it all straignted out. 

It was my youngest daughter's birthday and when we mentioned that to him he smiled and said happy birthday.  They don't give anytype of cake or ice cream.  Not that big a deal but you would think that for an "upscale" place in a nice hotel they could give you something, 

The only saving grace was the food.  It is way over priced, but it is good

Bottom line, a night of Wicked with the family was almost completely ruined because of the horrible service.  The saving grace was the evening being spent with loved ones celebrating a birthday
author: Tracy M.

description: We came here before the theater (seems like a common place to do so) and everything was great for the most part. The service was spotty at a couple of points but they were fairly full so it was really nothing major. Most of my group was late for our reservation (SF traffic) and the staff was kind about serving me and allowing me to sit at the table. 4/6 of our group had the ravioli which was fantastic-everyone said that that was the highlight of the meal. I had a beet salad (how I judge restaurants) and it was also lovely. Next time I go to the theater I would come back here!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Conveniently by our hotel "Whitcomb hotel" the waiter was clumsy. Spilled coffee all over the place. Food was average, not worth the price. Food took a while.

The lady by the entrance was very nice
author: Hatem A.

description:
Second time at Market Street Grill.  We were lucky to get a reservation (for 5) during SuperBowl50 week!    
Great food.  
Great service.   
Lovely old San Francisco ambiance.  
Highly recommend, especially if you're taking in a show across the street at the Orpheum!
author: Janice C.

description: We were staying at the Hotel Whitcomb for PRIDE (great location) and we were able to get a reservation for the Market Street Grill. Everywhere else was booked, including the Market Street Grill but we put our name in and luckily we got a table. First off, the location was brilliant for PRIDE and anything close to Market, especially the Orpheum; it's close to the action but far enough to catch your breath. Secondly, the food was great, I ordered the chicken and it was perfectly cooked. The waiters were so nice and had great recomendations. Everyone was so nice. Even the restaurant manager, Orion, came by to check on us. Very timely service and excellent customer service. I'd dine here again, definitely.
author: Luz S.

description:
I have been here numerous times before shows at the Orpheum and I have always enjoyed myself. This most recent time last night, we came in a group of 16 and they had reserved for us a private room with a prixe fixed menu due to our size. I usually like to have a full menu to choose from but this menu was really nice and I liked that each place setting received a personalized menu with our name on it.

I got the Lamb Chop and it was so beautiful and tasted really great. Everyone else seemed to really enjoy their salmon dishes and mushroom ravioli as well. The waiter was really cute and silly and personable, which I always like. There's not many places to eat before shows at the Orpheum but I'm glad this place is there because I don't feel like I am settling!
author: Alexandra W.

description: Omg... Was up north in San Francisco for the evening for the first time.. Ran into this place on accident... The food super delicious...the service...our server was sooo nice and explained dishes n choices of the day...  The food...omg...soooooo good... I would definitely suggest this place again when in the area or recommend it to anyone looking for a nice dinner place...
author: Sandra R.

description:
Quote :
"Great place for a great meal before a show "


 I ordered the Seafood  carbonara. It had Lobster , king crab bits peas and a raw egg. That surprised me but was really tasty . It is a tad on the rich side but it is good. I also sampled the spaghetti  and lamb chops. The spaghetti was a bit spicy with sausages . I would come back if i was in the area . Service was good as well
author: Michael T.

description:
This restaurant is tucked away inside the doors of Hotel Whitcomb. The Whitcomb's lobby is beautiful, by the way. We chose to eat here for it's close proximity to the Orpheum Theater, where we were seeing Rain.

When we stepped foot into the Market Street Grill, it felt as if we'd stepped back in time. Though very detailed in its decor, it felt very old-timey...and not in a retro vintage type way...more like a dusty old person type way.

The food was mediocre at best. It wasn't bad, but it definitely was not worth the expensive price tag.  The name is somewhat deceptive...when I think of a "grill," I think of a bar & grill...with a diverse menu...and perhaps entrees that are cooked...on a grill...no? 

Their small menu should have been a clue to the small size of their dishes.  If I'm paying $19 for a bowl of pasta, I shouldn't have to fill up on bread before leaving.
author: Monique C.

description:
Dine About Town Meal #2:

I've been curious about this place. It's the closest restaurant to work on the list. The location is deemed historic, however, I would describe it as outdated. 

My coworker and I both enjoyed our clam chowder. Cooked with thyme & bacon, not the best chowder I've ever had, but it was pretty darn good. Creamy but not-too-thick, just the right amount of potatoes, with flavorful bits of bacon. Mmmm. The bread was delicious as well. Basket full of sourdough, rye & olive pecan bread. Yum!

Onto the seafood linguine. We were exciting to see the other table with big creamy delicious dish of linguine. When ours came out, however, it looked nothing alike. Our sauce was dark and watery. To make matters worse, it was flavorless. Very very disappointing.

My sorbetto trio (mango, lime & raspberry) was refreshing and delightful. My coworker's creme brulee was disgusting. It was dark and dense, almost soggy.

Yay for big portions. But bad dishes were inexcusable. A very hit or missed experience.

Photos: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pqtF6dfpJDOMC2EMcaj6FQ?select=hUy-oF2ctM-ADAI_PHnOxA
author: Marti L.

description:
Nothing fancy and wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to come here next time.  It just happened to be there and we were starving.  The place is old but the age compliments the atmosphere.  The staff was attentive, almost too attentive in a way.  We walked in during the lunch hour and the place was only half full.  Our server was lingering around just waiting for me to make a demand of some sort.  I almost felt compelled to make him work as if i was the King of Old Market Street Grill and he was my servant just waiting for his orders.

All that aside, the food was average.  I had the french dip and the au jus was cold.  The sandwich and the bread were pretty decent though.  

The service was good so this place is A-OK!
author: Sunny C.

description: Please get a new chef. The venue and service was fine. We had the arugula salad that was a bit too salty and loaded with cheese and oil. As a main course we had salmon that tastes too fishy. I get better fish at Safeway    the potatoes were reminiscent of mashed potatoes from my college dining hall. Bland, watered down  and over cooked. We won't be going back (unless they get a new chef)
author: Terese D.

description:
Across the street from the orpheum.  Wicked started at 8 p.m., arrived at 6:50 no reservations.  Said they could seat us in ten minutes,  25 minutes later, we order as we sit down....

It's 7:15, can they do it?  Friend ordered crab cake, goes to bathroom, waiter comes back, no more crab cakes, what does she want?  Uh er

7:25 the salads come. Delicious!  Apples, pistachios , cheese, nice vinegerette.  Loved it

Great sourdough bread

7:40 the ahi tuna comes. It's an appetizer , but wow, very generous portion of tuna. It was great. The huge mound of ginger was untouched, who can eat that much ginger???

Waiter brings check with tuna, I pay while i eat, we get out of there at 7:50 and in our seats at 7:55

I thought everyone that worked there was nice, and even though it was 25 minute wait instead of ten minute wait as she first indicated, they do a good job getting you to the theater in time

I did feel as if I inhaled the food, lol
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Victim of being in a hotel the pricing is high for quality... Had the lobster Mac and Cheese which was pretty bland and the Caesar salad which was very sub par and did not have a Caesar dressing. Recommend kicking up the Mac and cheese with some Tabasco sauce for flavor.  Service is a little stiff but overall better than venturing out on market st. especially at night-

the main dining room has a nice large fireplace and it is not very crowded so may be good for a couple to enjoy
author: Rico P.

description:
Just another average spot on the pricey side for lunch I say, but that is typical San Francisco theater district for you! Especially so close to the Tenderloin border, there aren't many other sit down options near the theater, which makes this place pretty packed the hour before a show at the Orpheum.

We all got burgers. That's what makes up most of the menu here for lunch, but beware that they don't include fries or anything on the side! And it doesn't mention anywhere on the menu that you can order a side of fries or onion rings. Weird that they wouldn't put those printed on their menu I think...why are they secret?? The onion rings are very fried and battered but that made them extra extra tasty and bad for you at the same time. I loved every bite. The fries were okay. 

My burger came with capers and roasted peppers and swiss cheese on it BUT it was supposed to also come medium rare and it was definitely fully cooked. Strike 1 there.

I also had to ask for water twice, and if I hadn't asked I never would have gotten a refill it seems. Strike 2. We also didn't get the free bread that everyone else got in the room. Since we ordered burgers we decided we didn't need the extra carbs, but still. And then once the real theater rush came in, you didn't offer us dessert! We had to ask to see the options! Don't rush us out when we made a reservation and you didn't time appropriately to have enough tables. Good thing your burgers were actually pretty good, minus the whole not cooking them like they were ordered thing ha
author: Sarah G.

description: Nice pre-theater meal near Orpheum and Civic Center.  Lemon Ravioli is a standout. Short ribs also very good. Good cocktails. Efficient service paced to get people in and out for theater.
author: Claudia P.

description: We went here before seeing a show at the Orpheum. Yup, the service sucks as everyone has commented on.  We got there really early and it wasn't that busy yet the server was still slow on taking our order and being available. The service is not awful...it's just lackluster and the servers just don't seem to care. I asked him where the bathroom was and he told me it outside to the right of the lobby. I come to find out that you need a key to get in!  Who doesn't mention that? The food is okay, it was better than I expected but still pricey-$100 for 2 w/ one drink each.  This is the kind of place you find at the Wharf- food and service are mediocre because they don't care if you come back.  We opted to skip dessert there and walked a block over to Market Square (the food emporium) and got some great dessert and regretted not going there for dinner.
author: Puff G.

description:
My wife and I ate dinner at the Market Street Grill in the Hotel Witcomb last Friday before a performance of "Wicked" at the Orpheum Theatre across the street.  We arrived at 5:30 pm and the show started at 8pm so we had plenty of time.  

When we arrived, we were impressed by the very nice traditional decor. The restaurant has vaulted ceilings, a large fireplace at one end (which had a nice fire on it to warm a typically cold San Francisco summer day).  The chairs are high backed with hunting scene designs, the tables have white tablecloths (but with a white paper on top).   The bar area has beautiful stained glass ceilings and a stained glass window behind the bar.  It is good to find a place with such traditional decor in this era of ignoring history.  The restaurant entrance is inside the hotel lobby.  The lobby itself is a great traditional architectural gem with marble walls and columns an a carved wooden ceiling. 

At 5:30 pm, the restaurant was mostly empty.  We did not have reservations, and the staff said that it is a very full night (many reservations were made by theatre patrons), but they found a nice table for two for us between the fireplace and the windows looking out on Market Street.   Later, when most of the patrons arrived, the restaurant was completely full, so reservations look needed on theatre performance nights. 

Since we arrived 2 hours before the time we wanted to go to the theatre, we asked the water for a relaxed service to fill the time.  He agreed and everything was nicely paced.  [based on some of the other reviews, this probably insures a better experience].

Shortly after we were seated, a pianist began playing on the grand piano in the bar area. The music and the decor created a very elegant ambiance. 

My wife had the clam chowder soup which was very good, thick with clams.  The soup also had bacon in it which added a distinct flavor that she never had before and found very enjoyable. 

There was a bountiful bread basket with both a purple bread with walnuts and also sourdough.  The bread was average in taste.

My wife had the Parmesan encrusted trout, laid on a bed with asparagus, little potatoes, and tiny mushrooms. Very tasty. 

I had the Osso Buco.  I ordered it with extra sauce and I'm glad that I did, as the amount of sauce was just perfect.  The meat was tender and very favorable. The potatoes and carrots were an excellent compliment. 

I had a glass of Merlot wine (Cono Sur 2008, from Chile), recommended by the waiter, which went very well with the Osso Buco. 

For dessert, we had Chocolate Decadence and lattes.  The Chocolate Decadence was very rich and flavorful.  

Overall, we recommend this for a leisurely before theatre dinner.  It is a bit on the expensive side ($95 for 2 including tip).   

Parking is nearby, but the best parking deal is a block away at the SOMA Grand garage on Mission (between 7th & 8th): $10 for 4+ hours.
author: Mike M.

description:
We dined here before a performance at the Orpheum, as I think many people do.  The food was excellent. We had steak with fries, pretty average, Meyer Lemon Ravioli, Scallop Risotto and the special, which was Halibut with Mango Salsa.  The last three were remarkably good. We also had a Cesar Salad, which was average, Tomato Caprice - they did not use farm fresh tomatoes, and watermelon Gazpacho - excellent.
Service was not "personal", but efficient. Room was pleasant, but had dirty windows, which was quite obvious as it was a sunny evening. Staff came around to inquire as to how things were, and quickly brought us hot coffee when ours turned out to be tepid.
So a pleasant place, with good food, but missing that warmth that makes you want to return.
author: LaVerne P.

description: Nice place, kitty-corner ftom the Orpheum Theater.  Food was very good- we had the ravioli with "meyer lemon ricotta cheese filling" ($20) delicious. Not too lemon-y, as the sauce, which was delicious, had no lemon flavor.  The New York steak ($29) was very good, also, but arrived with fries.  WHY would a real restaurant even do that???  Do realize that the entrees include nothing else, so with 2 salads, 1 mixed drink, 2 coffees and no dessert, the bill came to $99 inc. tax.  With tip $115.  Not exactly a 2 $$ dinner! But the food, service snd atmosphere were definitely very good.
author: David H.

description: Mediocre food, really bad service, and moderately expensive.  This is the least enjoyable of the approximately 20 restaurants I've been to in SF.
author: Dan B.

description: I ate here for lunch during a business meeting and had the chicken salad sandwich.  The bread and french fries were delicious, and the chicken salad creamy.  If you like rich, it's an excellent choice.  My friend had the salmon....and it was clear that I was out-ordered because it looked absolutely perfect.  Service was good, and it was a nice place to have a conversation.
author: Mac P.

description: I'm sorry to have to knock stars off - especially when it doesn't have anything to do with the food or the service.   But I called twice in the same day and the phone went to voicemail.  I left messages detailing my request for reservations the same evening and unfortunately never received a return call to either message.  I eventually made our reservation via Open Table and we enjoyed a very nice dinner with very good service.  However, it is now three days later and no one ever bothered to return my calls.  I would have appreciated hearing back from them even after the fact.
author: D T.

description: Surprisingly good food, but sort of a shabby interior and mediocre service. We were just looking for a central location with American cuisine to meet for a quick dinner. I'd say this is a great spot if you're off to a show at the Orpheum, or staying at the hotel. But there are so many better places to go in San Francisco that I was disappointed we landed here. That being said, the wedge salad was delicious.
author: Lyza L.

description: Beautiful table setting. Our party of four enjoyed the food we ordered. The staff was courteous and efficient. We were served promptly and the waiter gave us four separate checks as we requested. We had plenty of time to get to The Orpheum for the Dame Edna Farewell show.
author: Susan C.

description:
Met some friends there for a few drinks and dinner last night. It's a nice looking restaurant with marvelously detailed stained glass areas over the bar itself. The drinks were good--thanks, Keith! We shared a delicious bottle of Valpolicella with dinner. ( light red wine from the Veneto). 
I was in the mood for a salad and a burger at the bar. The mesclun greens salad with Point Reyes Blue Cheese was very good. The burger and fries hit the spot too. Others had the rib eye and thought it was so-so. 
Service is great. We'll be back.
author: Thomas D.

description:
not the best place in the area but really convenient for dinner before going to the Orpheum. service was ok but they were out of the two desserts we ordered. we had the halibut which was good. 
overall nothing amazing but easy for a pre-show dinner/drinks.
author: A.c. D.

description: It is a great location for theatre going to the Orpheum.  Unfortunately we had some mediocre service and mediocre food.  $11 for a caesar salad that barely covered a small plate was surprising.
author: Nancy S.

description: A pleasant breakfast surprise.  Reasonable prices, excellent service, great food and a lovely old world setting.  Our group of eight was seeking a quiet restaurant with good food and moderate prices.  We found it right on Market Street adjacent to the Whitcomb Hotel.
author: Steve M.

description: Nice place for dinner before the opera. Good food and drink reasonably priced. Excellent service. Nice ambiance. Great location for a snack before or after any events near Civic Center. We had the pork chop and the osso bucco both of which were very tasty! Photographs posted. Easy walking distance to the opera house. I would definitely dine here again and would recommend it to others.
author: Lou S.

description: Very disappointing breakfast. Neither my wife nor I got close to finishing our meals because we just couldn't stomach the poor quality food. The "ham" was actually manufactured meet, and the oats were a clay like consistency.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
Came for a tasty but quiet breakfast. I found a pretentious waiter who thought I didn't belong, a poorly cooked set of potatoes, bacon and eggs with a slice of store bought wheat bread, and one redeeming factor: a tasty cappuccino.

I most definitely will not be returning.
author: Eric A.

description: This place is a gem!! We had dinner there last night before seeing a play at the Orpheum theater. By the way, the Theater is right across the street! Four of us dined there and we all ordered a different dinner. All were wonderful!! The ambience was perfect! White tablecloths, candles and even a lit fireplace! I had the ravioli and it was the tastiest I have ever had. My husband loved his spaghetti and would get it again. Our friends had salmon and the chicken and they both loved their dinners. We will be back for sure!!
author: SALLY B.

description:
My experience with Market Street Grill was fabulous! My two girl friends and I came in last Friday and the food, wine, and desert were all amazing. Our experience was made even better when the executive chef came out to chat with us and offered us his special dessert for the evening (fresh Belgian waffles with vanilla ice cream and a chocolate mango sauce underneath). SO GOOD. I am SO having waffles for dessert all the time now. 

We had such a good time chatting with the chef that at the end of our meal he came out and gave us three ladies complimentary Sambuca shots, which was completely unexpected and appreciated. 

It is a little on the pricey side for a basic meal, but the food was good and the service was excellent, so I would definitely come back!
author: Brandi C.

description: Friendly service, but very high prices for mediocre quality food. If you have a show at the Orpheum or other venue nearby, you may want to consider another place, even though this restaurant is across the street. Our steak was tough and overcooked, pasta was overcooked as well and lacked much flavor, and nothing was really memorable. Just very blah considering the cost.
author: Michael P.

description:
By virtue of location, this place should be THE go-to place for an Orpheum pre-theater dinner, but it's missing out on several fronts.  Frankly, given its location in a kind of nowhere part of town, the only reason I'd ever come here is for a pre-theater dinner or lunch.  What do they get wrong?

1)  They can't handle the rush.  One would think if your raison d'etre is to serve the pre-theater crowd that you'd be setup to handle the rush.  Last night, I dined there and they were clearly overwhelmed:  took 10 mins to get someone to ask if we wanted a drink, the manager was helping serve plates, my clams were cold because they sat waiting at the kitchen too long before being served.

2)  The menu is too fancy-wancy.  I don't want brick-pressed quail with truffled risotto before the theater.  More importantly, my kids don't.  It was very hard for my 13 year old to find anything to order.  Since no one wants dubious fancy food, they should simplify things.

3)  The decor is kinda old and ratty.  Not the end of the world, but they could use a facelift

Let me play Gordon Ramsay here (in the Kitchen Nightmares sense).  This place needs to cater to the pre-theater crowd with a special fast-service three-course meal where the selections are simpler, more limited, and served faster.  Think:  3-5 choices for each of starter / main course / dessert along with a fixed price and fast service.
author: Dave K.

description:
Had dinner here for NYE. The fact that it was pretty dead inside should have tipped me off. You would think that a restaurant of this caliber would have a host standing at the podium at all times. Even though there are no customers.

Anyways, we first ordered our drinks. Good to know they don't stiff you on the alcohol =) My strawberry daiquiri was good but they could have blended it a bit more. There was still chunks of ice so I couldn't use the tiny straws. 

We ordered the battered calamari with eggplants and chef's chosen cheeses. The calamari dish was good. The sauce has a bit of an after kick to it. The cheese dish was okay. Didn't really care for it. It would have been better with crackers instead of bread. Speaking of bread, the bread they give you for starters was cold and the butter was too hard to spread. Here's some advice, warm the bread or at least the butter.

On to entrees. I ordered the seared ahi tuna. My bf, the lamb chops. Our friends had the linguine pasta, steak, and salmon. My ahi tuna was disappointing. It seems the tuna wasn't really fresh and the seared part was really spicy and kinda nasty. The noodles was cold and tasteless. My bf's dish was okay. The lamb chops were a bit small. It seems the only good dish was the steak and salmon. Total was a little over $60 per person. Which to me was not worth it. I was still hungry afterward and was tempted to go to the Burger King across the street. Which in my opinion would have been a lot better. Also who ever heard of an automatic service charge for just 5 people? I can understand if it was for a party of 6 or 8 but 5? They must really be struggling for extra money.

All in all, I won't be coming back for more.
author: Kim B.

description:
You know what, if this place were only $$ I'd be kinder, but for the amount they charge, its pretty bad.  I'm in town, staying at the adjacent hotel, so I'm a captive audience (aka eaten here twice!)  For starters, they brought my entrée before I finished (or even half finished) my appetizer, which at a TGIFridays, would be totally fine, but at a so called $$$ restaurant, thats a major faux pas.  I'm a slow eater...shoot me.  By the time I got to my $20+ entre, it was cold...and I was pissed.  I might have let this slide, except once I tasted it, I realized I had better at the Olive Garden. People were nice, but they are massively overcharging for food that is NOT fine dining.

From the two times:
Point Reyes Blue Cheese salad: yum (too much dressing...so ask them to go easy)
 Crab Cakes: despite a fishy smell, surprisingly awesome.  

Second Visit: 
Tomato Bisque: eh, nothing special.  I added a lot of salt and pepper.
Chicken Scallopini: nothing special at all.
author: Katy T.

description: This is our reservation spot for any time we watch a show at the Orpheum Theater.  Quick and good service, price point is roughly $40-$50 per person with dinner, shared appetizer and wine.  I usually order steak and so far they've always got the cooking right.
author: Patrick C.

description: This was our second visit here as it is very close to the Orpheum Theater. The menu is small but has a very good variety. We were, however, disappointed that they would not serve us any food off the bar menu despite the fact that they left the bar menu on our table with the other menus. But the food we ordered was delicious. I had the Halibut special which, except for a tiny bit too much salt, was excellent. Boyfriend had the spaghetti with meat sauce and he ate every bite. Dessert was a perfectly portioned round of cheesecake with berries. The service was very friendly and accommodating and the atmosphere is warm. The Whitcomb Hotel is an historic hotel with a lovely lobby even though it's in a sketchy part of town. Lots of parking garages and lots around, though. It's a great option for pre-theater dining.
author: Elaine D.

description:
A lot better than I expected for a hotel restaurant.  It's a relatively nice place with excellent service across the street and a stone's throw from the Orpheum Theater.  It's inside the Hotel Whitcomb, an older hotel that's pretty well restored.  I had a pretty good hamburger, but the truffle fries were great.  The salmon was not warm and the caesar salad had too much dressing.  The chicken was fine and the clam chowder as OK too.  

Overall, a pretty good dining experience.  Great for those going to the theaters.
author: Doctor G.

description: While waiting for a show at the Orpheum it was a surprising find. Can't wait to come back and bring my whole family. Everything was absolutely perfect!
author: Susan D.

description:
Across the street, Market, from Orpheum Theatre.

Filthy sidewalk...with bums and 3SFPD cop cars...

But food was DELICIOUS !!
$15 filet mignon french dip sandwich..
$16 crab and avocado sandwich....
$9  clam chowder.

Very attractive  front dining room !!
Excellent service !!
author: Fefi F.

description:
First off, the hostess ran away to fetch her manager who explained to us there are six "Market Street Grills" on Market Street, and that she just wanted to make sure we were at the "right one". Do I look like pond scum? Did we look that terrible? We were at the right restaurant for New Year's Eve, and yes we do understand it was a fixed menu @ $60 a person sans wine.

The food was simply just not that good. My soup was subpar, the kobe-style beef was just plain boring, and the chocolate mousse for dessert too sweet and too big to finish. I think this place is fine for people without a well-developed palate, their presentation is o-kay, the hotel pretty but the restroom the restaurant sends you to is really terrible in the hotel. Why do you need to walk out of the restaurant to use the restroom? The hotel restroom requires a card key, at least the women's does. 

I give up. We had high expectations for this place and we were unsatisfied. For the money you spend, you should really be getting a finer meal. At a hundred dollars a person, we all walked away pretty tipsy off the wine but not very satisfied with dinner.
author: Angie C.

description: Horrible service. Horrible food. I would go to Burger King across the street, you'd get a better deal and meal.
author: Marcus W.

description:
I'll keep this simple....if you're going to a performance at the Orpheum, this is worth consideration.  Beyond that, ehhhhhhhh.

Two menus - theatre menu and standard menu.  Standard menu first...not sure WHAT they were thinking....."let's use a strange font, and randomly throw the price in somewhere in the description...and let's make the first five entree's Italian, just to really confuse the customer on what we offer!  Oh, and we've GOTTA cover those SF fees, so don't forget to overcharge".

Theatre menu - salad or clam chowder?  Chicken or fish?  Cheesecake or bread pudding?  Not to take away from ANY of those....but $35 for the above choices, even in SF, seems rather gouging.  The clam chowder WAS good....but not as good as what you'd get in a sourdough bowl on Pier 39.  The salmon (ok, I'm biased here as I cook the best salmon in the world (cough))....but it was ok.  Chicken was BARELY undercooked (but, frankly, that's better than the typical overcooked).  The cheesecake will DEFINITELY pucker your checks.  The bread pudding?  Actually, quite good.  

So this goes back to my entry point....going to see Wicked?  Not a bad choice of a pre-performance meal.  Otherwise?   Keep walking.
author: Bill O.

description:
Ate dinner here before Book of Mormon at 8pm.
Nice ambience and both the hostess and bartender were great, as well as the servers.
I had the quesadilla and it was bomb :)
author: Anna Z.

description: This was our choice for dinning on Valentines because of it's proximity to the Orphum. I read several reviews which we not flattering so I wasn't expecting a 'great romantic' experience, but did expect a nice dinner. I was very satisfied with our experience. My wife had the Lobster Mac n Cheese and loved it, I had a nice Beet Salad and Mushroom Ravioli. I enjoyed the laid back 'mature' ambiance of the room. Yes it is dated, but who wants to go to see the same 'style' in every restaurant. The serving staff can use a little more training and polish, however, the host and manager were very good, I noticed they were both accessable and attentive to ours and other tables that needed a little 'help'. Cheers and Thanks Mkt St Grill.
author: Charles M.

description: Came here with my daughter before the show and while the bartender was pleasant the food was incredibly disappointing. Both my daughter and I ordered the New York steak and not only was it incredibly hard to chew but it was so salty my daughter had to spit it out. Vegetables beyond over cooked and just as salty. When the manager came over it seemed as though it was a reoccurring problem and was incredibly nonchalant about it.  While they didn't charge for the food we didn't eat, they did leave the check for the glass of wine I drank.
author: Jeannie S.

description: mediocre ant BEST. Close to theatre which was great, but the food was way over priced for the quality. Took one hour for dinner to arrive even though we were there at 6:15 we had to rush through dinner to get to an 8pm show.
author: David C.

description:
The food was good size portion and flavor for the price paid, but there were not many options.  I do not like seafood, so I felt that the only thing there was to eat was one chicken dishes or one pasta dish.  I got the chicken, loved it, but the options were disappointing.

Also, the extra you spend on the main course, you save on the desserts which were very reasonably priced.

There was no bathroom in the restaurant though.  You had to go all the way out the restaurant and use the hotel's lobby bathroom.  As not being a guest in the hotel, that was weird.  And the bathrooms certainly were not as nice as the vibe of the restaurant.
author: Tammy S.

description:
My husband and I went to lunch here before seeing Les Miserable. I made a reservation for 12:30 and we arrived promptly on time. Though the atmosphere inside is quite nice the service was not! We didn't get our food until 1:25. I ordered a french dip with a side salad. Evidently, they reheated my plate in the microwave because the au jus sauce bubbled over the top and into the salad and the lettuce was warm. There was no time to send it back as we needed to be out of there in 20 minutes. The sandwich was horrible!

My husband ordered a pesto chicken pannini and fries. He barely touched his sandwich as it was dry and cold. I took a bite of his fries and they were cold, greasy and filled with garlic. I noticed lots of plates going back to the kitchen where people didn't finish their entree. Guess they didn't care for theirs either. 

Get  to the theater early and walk a few blocks for lunch or dinner. Don't ruin your afternoon or evening or special date in the city by going here for any kind of meal!
author: Andrew K.

description:
A-OK, Not great, Not bad.  I would say the biggest thing this place has going for it is how close it is to the Orpheum.  Decent chance I will come back next time I see a show there.

The food is nice, nothing to write home about but clearly fresh.  I had their special Risotto (I didn't understand it came with fish and shrimp) and the Risotto was very good.  I think they should have it on it's own since the fish was kinda Meh.

Given the sketchy factor of the area near the theater and all of that I would suggest this before a show.
author: Amy P.

description: Dinner before show at the Orpheum. Had the lemon and herb chicken. Sweet potato purée delicious!!  Chicken was a little dry and also a very small piece of chicken
author: Debbie P.

description:
7 of us had dinner here after a Saturday matinee at the Orpheum across the street (Avenue Q which was great but not what I'm reviewing here eh).  We made reservations online using opentable.com (ridiculously easy) for 5:30.  We arrived at 4:45 and had a drink in the adjacent bar which was full of fellow theater goers.  I checked in at about 5:00 and they said we could be seated now if we wanted.  We wanted.

Our server, Sol, was great.  He said he was new but he knew his stuff, was fast and funny.  We ordered wine and a few more drinks and then, after taking our dinner order, he returned with 2 orders of Crab Cakes, compliments of the chef.  Cool.  Those are a bit pricey on the menu so we'd skipped them.  Wow they are great.  Kel and I will probably order them again but share 1 order ($14).  For starters I had the Field Green Salad (good), Kel had Heirloom Tomato Gazpacho, yum (I tried it).  3 of the group went for the cheese plate which I snarfed off of, (thanks Pat), and one had the steaming sizzling mussels.  Everyone loved everything.  My entree was the Salmon and it was roll-my-eyes-back good.  Kel had the New York Steak and the pieces she let me try melted in my mouth.   I heard great things about the Sea Bass and the Portabello Ravioli as well.

Chocolate Decadence cake for dessert. Mmmmmm.  Not much bad to say about this place.  Nice decor.  Quiet, even though every table was full by 6:30.  A little expensive, so not an evey night or even once a week place (especially since it's all the way out in the city :-) ) We were sorta dressed up but in a very casual way.  We saw dressier people and we saw more casually dressed folks and nobody seemed out of place.  I totally plan on coming back, as BART is right outside the front door.
author: Len V.

description:
Don't let the crazy decor in this place scare you away.  We got excellent service and the food was as follows:  

Crab cake appetizer.  It was literally the best crab cake I've ever had.  It looks a little scary, but dig in.  

I had the salad that was a chef's special.  It was wedges of heirloom tomatoes, arugula, grilled watermelon, feta, mint, and a vinegarette dressing.  This was superb.  The sweetness of the watermelon with the tart tomatoes was genious.

Portabella ravioli:  Oh, man, this was good.  They got the flavor combinations perfect in this one.

Spaghetti bolognese:  I didn't try it personally, but apparently it was excellent even though it needed a little salt.

Fresh linguini:  It had small and large shrimp, small scallops, those long skinny mushrooms that I can't remember the name, and a white wine cream sauce.  This was the only dish of the evening that fell flat for me.  I literally added salt 4 times throughout the meal.  The seafood was cooked perfectly and not rubbery and everything tasted good, it just needed a lot of salt.
author: Tara S.

description:
The four of us were heading to Orpheum Theatre for Wicked and decided to dine at a nearby place. This place seemed decent and it had a great atmosphere when we walked in, however, dining at it is quite a different matter.

We were told to wait at the bar because we didn't have a reservation and because they weren't sure if they can even seat us. The bartender came by and asked if we wanted any drinks, but since we didn't know if they're definitely giving us a seat, we refused, and the bartender did not look happy at all.

Finally, we got a table and sat down. We ordered our food (an appetizer and an entree each), but only one person decided to have a glass of wine. The waiter looked pretty upset, but we thought, ah well. The wine came in the middle of the meal and the waiter was pretty rude about putting it down.

I got the black truffle risotto stuffed quail, with the artichoke bisque as my appetizer. Both dishes were ok. The artichoke bisque was a bit blend after a while because it really was just bisque with some cheese in it without much complex flavours. The stuffed quail was more disappointing -- the risotto was too soggy to the point that it felt like a runny paste, and the quail did not have much flavour to it. I did enjoy the huckleberry sauce on the side though. I did not have a taste of what the other people in my group were having, but the consensus was that they overcharge for the quality of the food.

That aside, throughout my dinner, the waiter was constantly bumping into my seat while he serves the next table, without ever apologizing. I know that it was a bit crowded, but it was getting annoying, especially during one of the times he almost knocked my chair over when I was eating.

At the end of the meal, we looked at desserts but also decided not to have any because at that point we were fed up with the waiter and the busboy's rudeness. However, when he learnt that we weren't having any desserts, he threw out a really sarcastic "Thank you very much".

Basically, the only time we were being treated nicely was when the waiter presented the bill to us.

Overall I still gave it a 2 because the food wasn't half-bad, just overcharged and I've had better at that price. However, I think the service was absolutely horrible and I would not visit that place again.

A last note: the place looks very classy but everybody goes in with jeans. I was a bit confused, were they just trying to act high class?
author: Alice C.

description:
i went down to the civic center for a training class last week and had no idea where to go for lunch, so i just stopped by this place. 

I didnt have to wait for a table which was great. but once i got seated it took the waiter 15 minutes to come around to give me water and to take my order... i mean yea i have an hour for lunch... but what if i didnt?! 

after he took my order... the bread came quick but i didnt get my spaghettini until about 20 minutes later!. so even though this place wasnt very busy... i witnessed two different customer come in to order and recieve their meal before mine came.  bizarre.....

Then, when i started eating my spagettini, i noticed that it was pretty damn spicy. which for me is great.. i love spicy, i just didnt expect it since the menu didn't state that it would be. See... if i brought my mom here and she ordered that... she would have puked. It's always good to tell your clients about a spicy dish man.. .not all can handle it! and even besides the spice level... it was just mediocre. 

and because of their "pace" at the restaurant, i ended up arriving back at work 2 minutes before i was due.... that was probably the first time i took a full hour just to get lunch! I didn't even get to do any of my errands!
author: amelia g.

description:
Very mixed feelings about this place.

Great location (very close to the Orpheum and Davies Symphony Hall), and very nice decor. We arrived at 6pm on a Saturday night. There were only two parties in the restaurant when we arrived (I wonder why?). The hostess was very nice, and the service was pretty good.

My chicken was dry and over-cooked. although my veggies, polenta and sauces were very good. My wife ordered the prime rib for $34. It was tough and not very tasty.
