Just like reviewer Alex K.'s experience, she ordered medium rare, and it was medium well.  She said her potatoes were very tasty, but undercooked. 

Our friends ordered the trout and the seafood linguini. They both said their dishes were very good.

Total bill for six people (including three glasses of wine, and three deserts) was $280.

Like almost every other review on this page, our overall experience was quite mixed.
author: Andy F.

description:
Like most of the clientele here, I went before a performance of Wicked at the Orpheum. Upon walking in I was surprised by the odd and old decor, it looks like it was traditional back in 1970 and hasn't really been touched since. Though, getting seated next to the big warm fireplace was a plus! Sadly it took a hostess a few minutes to even get to us waiting for a table and the waiter didn't even ask for our order for quite a while. Considering the previous reviews that showed that they care for showtimes, it didn't exactly show.

Ordered:
-Calamari: Ewww, the squid was tiny and covered it toooo much batter making it taste more like fried batter than fried squid. Very greasy and oily, this is not exactly what I expected for this 'upscale' restaurant.
-Seafood linguine- It named scallops as one of the major ingredients, but when the dish arrived it only had tiny little cheap frozen scallops with a mix of 'meh' quality seafood. The cream sauce was a little watery for my liking
-Spinach & Gorgonzola Ravioli- This was surprisingly good, yet seemed a little mass produced. It was simple, tasty and well garnished with some sprouts and nuts that brought out the flavors in the Gorgonzola all in a light pesto sauce. Although, this seems like something that could be easily made from Trader Joes!

We were lazy in going somewhere right across the street from the Orpheum, we should've gone a little farther where you get more for your money and more tastiness in your mouth. This restaurant also seems a little out of place in the Tenderloin, so go eat some cheap mexican or vietnamese food!
author: Nehal N.

description: Best nearby place for dinner before a show at the Orpheum. We've been coming here for several years before the shows and they're getting better. It's apparent the theatre crowd is important to these guys and they show it with genuine appreciation that we are there (despite very busy), crisp service and good food, wine and full bar. The energy in this place is high before an Orpheum show (last night I think it was packed out before the 8 PM Newsies musical. Recommended.
author: C C.

description: We came to this place for dinner on a week night, around 6-7pm and it was empty. The food was pretty expensive and not great. We also had to wait quite a bit for it to get delivered. Pretty sure one of our group got sick due to the mushroom ravioli.
author: Dawn S.

description: For the perfect spot before BOM at the Orpheum, you'd think this place can't loose. But unfortunately the service was slow and sloppy. My wife's steak was way over cooked. The rest of our dinner was just OK. The "Casual Acquaintance" cocktail were good.
author: Irv B.

description: Good: close proximity to Orpheum Theater. Bad:Overpriced, unremarkably cooked, meager portions. Good Caesar salad marred by jaw-breaking croutons. Salmon and sea bass were over-cooked and dry. Expensive short rib devoured in 3 bites. Shared apple tart dessert was good. A better dinner would have been just ordering 3 apple tarts.
author: Thann V.

description: I went here because we went to watch Lion King at the Orpheum.  Service was horrible. The drink glasses for the drinks we ordered, had fingerprints on them and lip marks- clearly unwashed and if washed, very poorly washed. Dessert was not worth ordering. I dont think i'll be coming back here again
author: K D.

description:
I was watching Wicked and wanted to grab a bite somewhere nearby . After some searching, we found Market Street Grill. The prices seemed reasonable and it was really close to the show. 

We made reservations but was running late but they didn't give us a hard time about it, which was great! 

We ordered the following: 
Crab Cakes - YUM! love the red sauce they drizzled over it and the crispy noodles that were served on top. 
Caesar Salad - GOOD! I usually don't like my dressing to be heavy and order it on the side but this time I didn't. The dressing wasn't too heavy and it wasn't drenched on. 
Seafood Pasta - YUMMY! The pasta was cooked just right and the sauce was great. 
Kid's Cheeseburger - it was HUGE! and really yummy! it's hard to mess up a burger 

I loved the service and it was really clean and nice inside. 

I would go back and try other things on the menu. Definitely a place I would recommend
author: Wendy K.

description: Ambiance and location are what this place has going for it. Food was so so, service was good though, but the coffee....oy vey!  Rarely do I get a cup of coffee that's so offensively bad, it was like someone rehydrated the ashes of my ancient Chinese ancestors, served them to me lukewarm, and then charged me $2 for the ordeal.
author: Jennifer L.

description: A group of 5 of us went for dinner before a show.  We were on a tight time schedule & they were very accommodating.  The food was excellent & all the substitutions that were requested were done.  Everyone thoroughly enjoyed their meals.  We would all definitely come back.  Loved the atmosphere with the fireplace & old time decor.
author: Katy W.

description:
The food and ambience were very good. The restaurant has a fireplace, old ceilings and walls, and it is worthwhile to walk through or hang out in the Ramada's lobby area. It is a good place to go with out-of-towners.

We had mushroom ravioli, which came with 4 or 5 large pillows, topped with frisee. I had a very nice salad. Portions were just right, not too big. The menu said that everything is seasonal and from local farms. 

The service is what keeps this from getting the full five stars. It was not very professional--the waiter started taking away wine glasses without asking if we wanted wine (we did), and he seemed to question everything we ordered. He had a few borderline rude exchanges with my sister. Otherwise highly recommended!
author: Sagruilla P.

description:
Ok- everything was ok. 
Food was ok, not very original or flavorful
Service was ok, efficient but not friendly
Atmosphere was ok- kind of there, but not anything special.

Basically, if you're not going to the Orpheum, don't go
author: Ben G.

description:
If you are going to the Orpheum for a Wed. matinee, this continues to be a good choice for lunch. However, if you show up for lunch on a Wed., as I did recently, and you are not in a hurry, you will be caught in the frenzy. In an effort to make sure the theater patrons make their showtimes, the restaurant pre-makes the salads. When my friend asked for a particular salad without the prosciutto, the waiter answered that was not possible! What?

The atmosphere is still great and the ambience very pleasant.

I made reservation for 12:30 (Open Table) and then called at  10 a.m. to say our party wouldn't arrive until 12:45. Still, and disappointingly, they gave our table away and we were seated in the bar, instead.

I still think this place has promise, but they have a way to go to get their total act together.
author: Joanna S.

description: We had great service at the Market Street Grill and good food. We shared a spinach salad with strawberries and chicken and had creme brulee desert. No clumsy service as previously reported, but swift and efficient service from Dan. And extremely convenient to the Orpheum Theatre.
author: Peter H.

description: Walked in, got seated right away. Nice decor and has a fire place. Fancy shmancy. Ordered the fish tacos, which was $13 for a plate of 3 and an ice tea for 3.25. Total here with tip, over $20. The tacos were pretty good, but won't beat your taco trucks fish tacos, and it's expensive. Probably won't be back here for that. Rather hit up the taco trucks in Oakland, $1 for a taco.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
I would not go back here again.  Ever.  Even if I'm gonna watch a show @ the Orpheum.  

Food - horrible.
Service - horrible.
Ambiance - even worse.

Food - 

Caesar salad = romaine lettuce with cardini dressing from safeway or any other supermarket.  $10 for what?  

Trout = "boneless" trout with arborio rice and green beans.  The boneless trout had bones, the rice was so mushy it was like eating oatmeal, and the green beans could have been eaten if i just had gums....no teeth.  No crunch to it - just a warm mushy blob of bland horribleness.

Lobster mac and cheese - frozen lobster, gritty cheesy clumps, and...blah.

Service - 

Horrible.  I walk in to check in our table....the maitre'd (or whatever you want to call her) looks at me and looks away.  Um. Yes, I'm here to dine obviously....  but no - you would rather just look away, okay....great.  Then we finally get seated and the first thing the waiter says is - order fast or else you'll have to wait, we are planning to have a full house.  How about...hello - how are you?  But no....all we get is a notion that hte chef cannot cook for a whole restaurant - shocker....  I guess it's a good thing since no one will go here anyway so not like he needs to be prepared for a full dining room.

Ambiance -

It was decorated with a Christmas decorations so I'll give them that.  But the seats were so old and the place was dark - it just gave a look that needs updating....really bad.

All in all - don't go here.  no need to torture yourself and pay so much for food that you wouldn't want to eat.
author: Christopher L.

description: Took forever to get any service.   And there was a piece of plastic in our chicken pesto pasta!!!  Manager offered 5.00  discount, did bother to come talk to me or anything.  If I am trying save money I will have subway across the street!
author: Barry C.

description:
Our party of nine had dinner here on Friday night prior to attending Wicked.  We got there at 5:30 to avoid the rush and hopefully get our food in a reasonable amount of time.  Didn't help.  Some of us got our appetizers and soup quickly, but the main entrees didn't come until 45 minutes later.  We asked our server twice, and each time he said he would check with the kitchen, but then disappeared and never told us the status.  When we did get our food (mahi mahi, seafood pasta), it was ok.  Nothing really stood out.

Having been already somewhat disappointed, one of us noticed that there was some white gunk on the inside bottom of one of the water glass.  It looked like either dried milk or maybe caked on detergent.  The manager apologized and comped dessert.  Overall, a disappointing experience given the prices.
author: William L.

description: Located near the Orpheum theatre which was great.  Food was good and staff was pleasant.
author: Charles W.

description:
Dinner before a musical at Orpheum, Wed 04/11/12. Looking for something close-by besides fastfood. Been at Market Street Grill a few times over 20 years, always just OK and overpriced. This time: quite good and overpriced. 

Two of us at dinner, male and female. We split a $32 rib-eye steak. Steak was prepared and cooked with appreciated attention, including restrained seasoning that we welcomed, served with tasty grilled asparagus done just right and delicious garlic mash potatoes. Steak was large, the size more than we expected, so splitting the meal proved to be a wise choice (as we were a little pressed for time before the theater and we did not want to take leftovers with us). A wine drizzle/sauce/reduction on the steak (and artistically drizzled across the plate), so presentation showed some finesse. Bread was fresh (if unspectacular sourdough); butter was good, authentic butter. 

Hostess was pleasant, seating quick. Waiter was unsmiling, efficient, thorough. We were surprised the dinner was as good as it was, given past experience and these reviews. But maybe, it seems, the restaurant has been upgraded with a fine chef.
author: Miles H.

description:
** update **

New sheriff in town (new executive chef).  The menu is redone and the offerings are well to put it lightly, revolutionary (compared to what the items were before).

the osso bucco is to die for.  The new mac and cheese with truffle oil..OMG!  And the quail was succulent (and I don't think I've ever had a succulent quail before).

If you've rated it down before, go again and try it again.  I believe you'll be surprised at the changes.
author: Christopher C.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate here before seeing Wicked.  This was one of the only nice places to eat at for a pre-show dinner.  Since we only had about 45 minutes before the show, we ordered mostly appetizers.  

We ordered the kumamoto oysters shooters with sherry-black peppercorn granita, spicy "fritto misto" of calamari, rock shrimp, eggplant & zucchini with delicious sriracha aïoli to dip it in, and split a smoked chicken salad with bloomsdale spinach, english cucumber, fennel, and avocado plus a glass of wine.  Everything was sooooo good.  The kumanoto oyster shooters were one of the best oysters i've ever tasted.  We wanted to order a dozen oyster shooters, but they only had 4 left.  The calamari and all the other fried goodness hit the spot and the chicken on the salad was right on.

We ordered just the right amount of food and  went to the show very satisfied. =)
author: Anna Liza P.

description:
I can't believe how bad the food was. 

Truffle mac and cheese-- didn't taste the truffle. Mac was overcooked, the cheese was mostly butter.

"Kobe" beef burger:
The outside of the bun was soaked in butter (how am i supposed to grab this thing without getting burger butter all over my fingers?), the meat was mushy and not at all rich. 

Service wasn't actually horrible, but it wasn't good either. Somewhat awkward.

But, all around, a bad experience. I will not come again.
author: Ezra Justin L.

description:
Like everyone else, decided on this place due to it's proximity to the Orpheum Theatre and Wicked.   We were quickly seated which was nice, and told the waiter we were going to see the show and only had 40 minutes before we had to be out the door and on our way.  

I will acknowledge this was cutting it close, but we ordered "easy" things: clam chowder, tomato caprese salad and the crab cake to share.  Still, it took almost 30 minutes for the food to come out.  Given that 90% of the restaurant seemed like they were going to the show I would expect a little more organization during crunch time.  

The food was actually pretty good, drinks were not, and it was all a bit pricey.  For the three items above and two drinks we spent $60.  

The reason for the low mark was the service.  Our waiter took our order quickly, but that was about as far as the helpful service went.  I don't recall a greeting or even a smile. He seemed a bit annoyed by all of us theater goers in a rush. (news flash - don't work at a restaurant across the street from the Orpheum)  He brought out my drink, but not my friends - didn't even acknowledge it was coming.  We had to ask again about 10 minutes later, at which point he did get the drink without explanation or apology.  We were getting nervous when our food hadn't appeared after 20 minutes (again, appetizers and soup) and had to flag him down.  The table next to use seemed to have some issues as well.  The waiter was definitely on auto pilot.  Perhaps he should acknowledge the food service industry isn't his calling.    

In the end we made it in time for curtain (you really can't beat the location) but left a 10% tip.  I'm sure he cursed us out and wonders why people who go to the theater are cheap, which in turn causes him to treat the customers with disdain, resulting in more bad tips.  Cause and effect dude.
author: Heather H.

description:
We made reservations despite the mixed reviews.  The wife had always wanted to try it (she used to work up the street) and we had tickets to Wicked.  Normally, I'd say Tu Lan, but who wants to smell like tasty Vietnamese food during a performance?

We were a half hour early and seating was no problem.  Luckily, we were steered away from a window table, which would have been awkward (eating foie gras while looking upon Market Street's depravity, and them looking back is, well, weird).  

The dining room is one step below Liberace, with dark oak panels, really awesome chandeliers and dark maroon velvet.  I liked it!  But it is easy to make fun of.

Our hostess was bubbly, but our server was flat.  Actually a little gruff which didn't match his white waiters jacket. His lack of warmth didn't bother me, per se , but I did notice it.

While overall tasty, the food (like Wicked -- oo!) was uneven.  We had, among other things:

- Fox island mussels, fresh anise, spoon mustard, ponzu reduction ($11) -- Salty and sour and actually really tasty.  The caramelized ponzu was really intense, and there's no dunking broth, but  it was good.

- Dungeness crab cake, warm sweet corn & bacon salad, mustard dressing ($14) -- Large cakes, very tender, mild crab taste.  Crispy fried mystery fronds topped the dish.  Middle of the road, but tasty.

- Seared Sonoma foie gras with seared pork belly ($16) -- Easily the best dish.  A winner.  I'm guesstimating the price, but I remember I thought it was really low.  The piece of foie was very generous.  It was a liiiitle gamy, which I thought was okay.  The pork belly was more like a pork shoulder with long filaments of meat surrounded by tasty charred fat.  The garnish of unpeeled, grilled cantaloupe wedges was so bizarre.  My wife and I said WTF at the same time.  It looked horrible but once peeled was really tasty and went with the fatty meat.  

Going to Market Street Grill, I understand the mixed ratings.  The restaurant has many contradictions.  Upscale interior, but inelegant service.  Upscale ingredients, but uneven execution.  

The wife hit the nail on the head:  it's about your priorities.  If you priority is to  have a decent dinner before a show with a restaurant that understands you're on a schedule, this is your place.  If your priority is to have a well executed dinner with polished service, and you're not going to a show, there are other options you'll probably be happier with.

Overall tasty and pleasant, but it's not a destination restaurant.
author: Scott L.

description:
Scene:  Our company holiday party.  Plans:  See Wicked at the Orpheum Theatre.  Need:  A local restaurant to enjoy dinner before the show.

The best location choice was obviously Market Street Grill.  I had been there before and was not all that impressed and the yelp reviews were not encouraging.  But here is the scoop.  There is a new chef in town.  I booked this with a bit of trepidation but I thought I'd try out the new chef.

We had a set menu and here is what we tried.  Many had the crabcakes including my husband and they were really awesome.  One huge cake with lots of crab and beautifully presented.  The clam chowder got RAVE reviews from one and GREAT reviews from another (one loved the bacon better than the other).  I had the beet salad and it was exactly as described and good.

The meal selections were salmon which was served in what appeared to be a very thin taco salad shell and most had that and everyone loved it.  The ravioli was very good per my husband, my pasta was really wonderful with tiny scallops and large prawns.  The NY Strip steak got RAVE reviews from the two that chose that.

I fought to get the chocolate decadence on the menu - because let's fact it - you gotta have chocolate.  My husband had the cheesecake.  This is hands down the best cheesecake I have EVER had.  It was far more "cakey" than most and truly awesome.  I would love to be able to replicate it myself but probably a good thing I won't be able to.

So, in short I would say - give the Market Street Grill under the tutelage of Chef Ying Kee a try.  

I realize this review might seem "planted" but I promise it is true.  

By the way - parking was awesome!  Go down Hyde cross Market and make an immediate right into the parking lots that charge $20 for the full event.  Go down that street and enter the Whitcomb Hotel.  You don't even need to walk to Market and over and it was raining so that was great!

Judy
Redwood Skytours Travel Agency San Rafael
author: Judy H.

description: When you leave without dinner, it's not a good experience. We arrived at 6 pm and ordered promptly because we had theatre tix. The service seemed a bit frazzled so we thought it best to get our order in right away. Alas, we got 3 out of 4 salads and had to track down a server to get the fourth salad.  An hour later our waiter reported that the kitchen was overwhelmed and he had no idea when we might be served. It turned out that by 7:40 they had nothing to serve. Our waiter brought the check for our salads (amazing that they would charge us at all). The chef came over and apologized, but there was no explanation for the worst service of the year.  There does not appear to be any management here and the hostess is rude. No reason to eat here.
author: Marcy B.

description:
Eh. 2.8 stars.  This place was less than okay.  One of the few decent dine-in restaurants near the Orpheum Theater...
Got seated right away. Service was decent, but a little slow.  Food was just ok, nothing special...same type of steak, salmon, mashed potatoes you would get if you ate at a hotel banquet.  The desserts were a little better than ok. We had the apple crumble with ice cream and also ordered the bananas foster flambé.  The banana foster only required a donation (of $12) to help support the leukemia an lymphoma society.  We gladly got it because we've raised money for this cause before and we wanted to have a show before our actual show at the Orpheum.  We got out just in time to make it to our show even with the mistake on our tab.  We were charged an extra drink and the total was off for some reason. Our waiter seemed apologetic, but it turned our ok dining experience into one that was kind of annoying.  I wouldnt recommend a friend to go here unless they were short on time and wanted to grab a bite before heading to the Orpheum. I won't be back.
author: Marjorie P.

description: While the atmosphere is nice and the location is convenient to the Orpheum Theatre, the service and food are lacking. It took a long time to get our Caesar salad and then our meal. Our daughter's lunch salad came long after everyone else's food and one person didn't get the au jus with their French dip. The food presentation was good but everything was consistently tasteless. Won't be going back.
author: Kelly Y.

description: Loved it!  The Market Street Grill is located in the Hotel Whitcomb.  It has a very nice ambiance and the best part....it is close to the Orpheum Theater.  We are able to get a good parking place across from the theater, walk a block to the restaurant, and have a very enjoyable, relaxing meal at the Market Street Grill before walking to the theater. The menu was varied and had several fish items, which we always look for when dining out in SF.  Loved the soup, the salad, the wine menu, and the dinner.  There are better places to go in SF if you are in for a fabulous dining experience, but if you want convenience to the theater in a pleasant atmosphere, this is the place to go. The wait staff could use a little more training, but the bussers were great.  I'll go back again when I'm seeing something at the Orpheum.
author: Lisa Critie H.

description: We met some relatives here who were seeing a show at the theater across the street later that night There are not too many options around this area, so they made reservations at the Market Street Grill. I didn't have high expectations after reading fellow yelpers' reviews, but I was pleasantly surprised. We indulged in a delicious bottle of Pinot Noir, and gulped up the fresh sourdough bread they brought us to start with. We probably went through three baskets of bread. I guess you can say we were all starving! When it came time to order, the server asked us if we were going to the show, so that they could keep an eye on the time. I thought that was very smart and considerate of the server. It was like he didn't want us to rush. Anyway, I ordered the spring salad to start with, and the chicken for my entree. The salad was really fresh with goat cheese, pistachio, and arugula topped with a light vinaigrette dressing. I actually wished I hadn't shared it with my hubby - it was that good. The chicken was very moist and tasty. My husband enjoyed the ravioli, along with another person in our party who also ordered it. Although I wouldn't go out of my way and sit through Market Street traffic just to come here for dinner, it is absolutely the best option if you want a good quick dinner before a show. I really didn't find anything wrong with the Market Street Grill. P.S. They have a nice bar too.
author: Kelsey K.

description:
I'd like to give this place 3.5 stars - while I am not likely to dine here often in the future, I was impressed by the quality of the food and the dining experience set up the rest of the evening (at the Orpheum) really nicely.

From what I can tell, this is more the place you take your mom* than a date (whoops).  The lighting is too bright, the dining room doesn't have any private nooks and the furniture is outdated.  But, they did have a fireplace.

Given the atmosphere, I was expecting pretty good food - nothing too amazing, but it had better not be bad.  Overall, the food was creative and delicious.  Nothing was best-ever category, and nothing was bad.

-The cheese plate came with a blue, a stinky, and a mild goat.  The raisins were noteworthy.  Toast points would have been better than the thinly sliced but inexplicably high surface area bread slices.  Good plate.
-Oysters came with a very interesting vinegar slushie.  This product would be fantastic to see twirling around a machine at 7-11.
-Tuna sashimi was my favorite part of the meal.  Just a little soy and jalapeno oil added complexity to the mounds of raw fish, garnished simply with fried won-tons.  Maybe a little grenery for texture would have added something.
-Salmon was very interesting.  It came barbequed a top a mix of mu shu greens and a fried mu shu pancake.  And yes, there was plum sauce.  Never seen anything like it
-My ravioli with gorgonzola, walnut and quince were pleasers.  Incredibly rich and decadent.

The waitstaff, once they finally came around, seemed a little overly concerned with getting us to our show on time. We came in two hours before show time and were across the street.  Let us finish our mounds of fish before you bring the entrees, would ya?

*Though I have to say, my mom would have NOTHING to do with those bathrooms, which could be mistaken for a public park loo if it weren't for the 80's pink tile.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I had dinner here because it seemed the closest walking distant restaurant before watching Wicked.   

It's a nice restaurant inside, nice wait staff and the food was decent.  The chicken was actually really good, my steak was good, but not the greatest.  I asked for medium and they brought it well done.  The only really disappointing part was the salad.  I got the apple salad and it was like they went out and ripped up some weeds and threw some shredded apples in it with some nuts that were suppose to be candied, but definitely didnt seem like it to me.   Besides the salad, everything else was good.....especially the wait staff.   

I probably wouldn't go there again unless I had to go to a show, but it is definitely a good place to go right before a show.
author: Alex K.

description:
I too came here due to it's close proximity to the Orpheum and I wish that I had had a bit more time to find somwhere else to go. The main course here was great. If it was in a different restaurant with different service I would go back. 

The salad left something to be desired... little dressing, and the lettuce was brown. I ordered the salmon and it wasn't cooked all the way thorugh but the flovor was great. The polenta was amazing. My date ordered the Prime Rib. It was phenomenal. A huge helping and great flavors. The service was so bad that we almost left after we oredered. We werent asked if we wanted wine, we didn't get bread until we finally asked the bus boy because our waiter was nowhere to be found. I hope that this experience was an isolated event but I wont be back to confirm that.
author: Stacey L.

description:
This restaurant has the same old-world charm and elegance as the Whitcomb, the hotel in which it is located. The food is traditional, but well prepared and the service friendly and efficient. Conveniently located near Civic Center, on nights with opera, ballet or symphony performances it is a more leisurely alternative to the crowded eateries on the westside.
Renate C.
author: Renate C.

description:
If I could give it less then 1 star I would.

The only reason we ate here is because there is nothing else nice to walk to for resturants. 

The service was horrbile, the clam chowder was bland, the salmon was over cooked and TINY, the tuna was 3 pieces and lame.

The hostess asked us 5 times if we only had 2 people, and the place was empty.

SKIP this if you can!!
author: Nicole B.

description:
They required that because we were in a large party, that we order from the price fixe menu in advance, even though some items were "fish of the day" and the like. We ordered our meal probably a week ahead of time. They definitely knew we were coming. The poor waitress was severely overworked and we saw her at most every 15-20 minutes. Drinks that were ordered at the beginning of the meal arrived after desert. Ordered refills never arrived. I was unable to even get the waitress' attention to order a refill for half an hour.

They claimed that there was a mix up and misplaced our orders, but they miraculously found them when someone ordered from the other price fixe menu and his original order arrived. The portions were somewhat small but this wasn't made up for by the food being excellent. The food was tepid, the salmon was dry, and the risotto was slightly crunchy. I expect more for the price that they charged us, plain and simple.

And then the final indignity, yes, I was in the party with Amy L. and Jessica S below. Everyone in the party who used a credit card was double charged. The restaurant is claiming in each case that the parties simply paid for two parts of the meal-- two identically priced parts of the meal even though drinks were involved. On two different days. Right.

They are refusing to issue chargebacks. Unfortunately, 2 of the people who were double charged used debit cards, not credit cards, so the only thing that the bank can do is declare the transaction to be fraud and cancel the card. That means that all of their automatic payments will have to be changed simply because this restaurant can't admit that it made a mistake.

I was simply going to warn people I know that if they are going to the Orpheum, that this restaurant is overpriced, under staffed, not tasty, and incapable of handling the Orpheum load. But I chalk those things up to being incompetent. I can't chalk this credit card thing up to being incompetent.
author: Jen L.

description: Before going to see Phantom at the Orpheum, 5 of us came here for dinner.   We were all very pleased with our meals, cocktails and service.    Three of my friends had filet mignon which they all said was terrific, cooked properly and very tender.    I had the watermelon gazpacho, totally delicious, and Caesar salad with grilled salmon on top.   Very nicely done, not over dressed, very fresh salmon.   The fifth person in the party had grilled salmon steak with mashed potatoes and vegetables.   All the plates were beautifully presented.   Our wine and cocktails were prepared very well.   Their house Merlot was one of the best I've tasted (forgot to ask which winery it was from).   Our waiter was very attentive and we got out in 1.5 hours, plenty of time to get to the theater on time.   The restaurant is decorated very nicely, old-style decor, which I love, warm feeling.  All in all, it was a great beginning to our evening, topped by the BEST Phantom we've seen.
author: chris k.

description:
My boyfriend and I and a few friends had dinner here before attending the show, Wicked.  We had no RSVP and were seated within 5 minutes even thought the place was entirely packed they tried to squeeze us in. :)  

The waiter took our orders quickly and made sure our drinks and food were out, understanding that we had a show to catch.

Well if that isn't service, something is wrong with you haha! We had the truffle rissotto stuffed quail, kumamoto oysters, crab cakes, chicken with hoisin egg noodles, fois gras, and gorgonzola ravioli.  

The food came out warm but hey it was pretty tasty! We had an excellent meal and were on time for our show :)
author: Harry K.

description:
This is the 2nd time I've been to the restaurant and still A+ experience.  We usually hold our association mixer here right before a tour at the Asian Art Museum (which is literally right around the corner).

We had the nook in front of the tv for our mixer.  They cleared out all the tables and chairs so we had more room to move around.  They even went as far as help pick out 4 - 5 items on the appetizer menu for us to start.  Food, just as last year, was just delicious.

On the menu:

- fox island mussels, fresh anise, spoon mustard, ponzu reduction
- spicy "fritto misto" of calamari, rock shrimp, eggplant, zucchini, sriracha aïoli
-dungeness crab cake, warm sweet corn & bacon salad, mustard dressing
- artisan cheese plate
- pomme frites

No problems with asking them to refill the food nor close out the tab.  Definitely will be coming back again for a 3rd time next year.
author: Natalie P.

description: This place is aweful, if it weren't the only restaurant/bar near the orphium, I would've gone somewhere else! First off, the name Market Street "Grill" is deceiving, it is not at a grill type restaurant. Extremely small menu choices and all overpriced for the quality. My salmon was plain and overcooked, and the $15 crab cakes is really just one poorly cooked cake. I've had better frozen crab cakes. Now the bar tender is another issue, old, rude and overworked and can't make a drink to save his life. With an open bar and no drink menus , we gave him an ingredient list for a drink and he totally screwed it up. It was completely undrinkable and he refused to make me something else. And if tha wasnt bad enough, as we were sitting in the bar all we could smell was sewage and it was noticeable to everyone else around us as well. Next time I'll go to burger king across the street!
author: Corinne H.

description:
So dine about town is around again and this establishment was listed. My lovely friend made reservations for party of six and when we got there, we were told that they don't do weekends. The Maitre D' however after arguing (well, explaining some would say) about the mistake on booking, decided to still offer the prix fix menu. 

What I had: san francisco clam chowder (zoe's apple smoked bacon, thyme), molasses marinated fulton valley chicken breast (garlic-parmesan noodle galette, baby bok choy, lemon emulsion), and butterscotch creme brulee. Chowder alright, chicken dry, noodles ehh bland, baby bok choy over steamed/cooked, and the brulee disappointing. 

my friends had short ribs (dry), salmon (alright), sorbet (syrupy-cant tell flavors), caesar salad (alright), spaghetti (disappointing), and tea (one person really liked the spices in it).

It wasn't bad enough to get a 1 star, but I'm almost tempted because the wait staff we had was in my opinion--rude. Would I go back? Hell no.
author: Eva L.

description:
Given the mixed reviews, I didn't have too high expectations for this place, but it was actually pretty good. We came here for dinner before seeing a play at New Conservatory Theatre (on Van Ness). True, the decor is a bit staid, but the food and service were good.

Since we were in a bit of a pre-theater rush, I asked the waiter if he could bring our appetizers and entrées at the same time. He said he'd try, and while everything didn't come out exactly at once, our main dishes were ready just minutes after our crab cake appetizer came. He also brought out an ahi tuna appetizer on the house, which was a nice surprise! For my main course, I had the chicken breast, and it was good. Nice sauce.

Despite our briskness, we still had time for dessert, and I had the bread pudding. Eh, it was all right. It could've been smoother and less crusty.

So I'd probably give this place three stars, and a plus-one for the prompt service and free appetizer. And by the way, they're on OpenTable.
author: Jeff T.

description:
The food's consistently "ok", not fabulous but for the neighborhood, it's better than Carl's Jr. down a couple of block.  I took sister to see "Wicked" before it closes in Sept. and she decided to treat for dinner.  She had the "rich" and filling seafood pasta with a white creamy sauce and managed to finish most of it.  I ordered the osso bucco which was too dry but not over salted and tasted good with the fingerling potatoes and tiny carrots which were more chewy than crunchy.  I didn't need it, but tried the lemon brulee', $9. It had a hint of lemon flavor but the texture was quick thick, more custard and near cheesecake-like.  I thought it was ok, but wouldn't order it again.  The topped it with a nicely rounded 1/2 sphere of spun sugar, really cool looking.  It's the closest restaurant to the Orpheum for dinner but you'll probably get better food if you're willing to trot down a couple of long blocks thru the depressed neighborhood and street people yelling at you to Farmer Brown's.  

Staff here is very nice, all Asian.  You need a electronic swipe card to go to the bathroom, which is located on the other side of the hallway outside the restaurant.  When we went, it was full of teens with luggage, I presumed who were checking into the building hotel.
author: Ry T.

description:
okay, i don't get it. there are so many mediocre/bad reviews of this place, and i had the complete opposite experience, as well did my friend.

don't let the surroundings of the often crummy vibe of the tenderloin steer you away from this gem, it is top notch. really.

we went to a matinee of west side story. the same day as the giants parade. complete mayhem. while we were trying to manage the crowds, we decided to see if there were reservations for after the play, which the hostess graciously arranged.

the decor was beautiful, the vibe mellow, and we found the food delicious. i had the clam chowder and the parmesan encrusted trout, both wonderful. my friend had the tasty spaghetti dish.

the price? i have had many worse meals in the city for double the price. our delicious rasberry cosmos cost more than the food, so we found it reasonable.

everyone has complained about the service and almost being late for their shows, etc. it is a restaurant, people. you need to allow yourselves time to eat. and the first thing they asked was if we were going to the theatre so they could get started on our dishes, so i am not sure i get it, although restaurants can have off nights. 

if you want fast food, go the subway or the burger king down the street. if you want a quality, reasonably priced meal with top notch service, go to the market street grill.
author: nicole p.

description: horrible and expensive. everything was frozen. they only had one dessert. the coffee was stewed, we asked for a new pot and they gave us instant!
author: Susan C.

description:
I went here last week for a pre-show dinner.  I was expecting to hate it.  Everything about it looked so typically hotel dining room.  But I liked it.

First of all the staff knows how to work the pre-theater rush.  I didn't feel like they were rushing me but it was clear they knew their mission.   Pretty much everyone there came and left at the same time and things worked like clock-work.

I had a delicious salmon with an heirloom tomato gazpacho (with goat cheese foam) starter.  I loved them both.

This isn't the best restaurant in S.F. by far but it will be my pre-Orpheum stop from now on.
author: Robert A.

description: Tried it twice before writing this review and I am happy to report that both experiences were good. The atmosphere is comfortable, almost cozy and warm. Fireplace adds lots of charm. Service was timely, food was creative and delicious and BEAUTIFULLY presented. Definitely coming back!
author: Ann K.

description: Good Food, nice atmosphere. I had a HUGE sandwich and the desserts look great too. This was a recommendation from the SF Hyatt I was staying at for business. I would come back next time I am in town.
author: Matt H.

description: Perfect choice for dinner before a show at the Orpheum! Nine of us enjoyed a delicious meal before attending the Book of Mormon. We will definitely go back to the Market Street Grill.
author: Russell P.

description:
One of the worst dining experiences I've ever had in SF, and I've lived here for years.  The waiter was mostly just inattentive but was sarcastic  when he got around to taking our order.  We waited 30 mins for a *very* small portion of ravioli for my bf (he said it was so-so, def not worth the $) and a burnt hamburger.  I'd asked for medium, so I sent it back and watched my bf eat his few scraps of food.  Afterward I went to Sam's Diner across the street for better service and less expensive and tastier food.

*If you're looking for something more upscale than Sam's before going to the theater, Heaven's Dog is a 5 min. walk away on Mission and 8th (1148 Mission) and way better.
author: Chris R.

description: Expensive and a little slow on the service side but it was convenient to the Hotel Whitcomb and the interior is fancy. I enjoyed sitting by the fireplace. The food was decent as well.
author: Cowboy B.

description:
A friend and I attended an all day city and county of San Francisco
retirement seminar yesterday at the Hotel Whitcomb.  With just an 
hour for lunch, we opted for the Market Street Grill rather than one of
the fast food choices across the street.  It looked quite inviting with its
large chairs and the chef was actually out front, checking on things as
we entered.  I said, "I hope everything's good."  He responded, "every
thing on the left and the right side of the menu is excellent."  It wasn't
until I opened the menu that I found it only had a left and right side.

Everything we had was excellent, however, from our raw kumamoto oysters on the half shell with sherry-black peppercorn granita to a
wonderful artichoke soup topped with a taste of feta cheese.  I had
a spicy "fritto misto" of calamari, rock shrimp, eggplant  and young zucchini with a sriracha dip.  My friend had a lovely field green salad
with enochi mushrooms.  It was just perfect 

The dinner entrees sounded enticing, with a great deal of variety, and 
I would not hesitate to go back again for a pre- or post - theatre meal.
Service was excellent.
author: Carmen H.

description:
I don't know if it was an off night but I do not agree with all of the favorable reviews of this place at all!!! The dishes were presented beautifully but I ordered an heirloom tomato salad and the tomatoes were bad. The bread was cold and stale. My entree was not terrible but really lacking in flavor. The food tasted a bit better after a glass of wine.
The hostess also had a really bad cold and had to stop and sneeze when I went up to the register to pay. I also thought it was odd that I had to go to the register to pay. I read the bio on the chef and had high hopes but was really disappointed. The decor could have been charming but the "old" smell was distracting. It is convenient because it is walking distance from the Orpheum.
author: Nina P.

description:
We chose thise place because of it's proximity to the Orpheum Theatre, and I slightly regret not going a little farther away!  We were greeted politely by a young woman who ended up being our server.  I was on crutches and she started escorting us towards some stairs obviously blind to the crutches and large knee brace I was wearing.  I paused and looked at her and she just said again for us to follow her, and then it hit her like a ton of bricks that I may not b able to walk up the stairs.  It was kind of rude, and I was extremely annoyed but we went up there anyways as she didn't make any true effort to rectify the situation.  She was very polite but could use a lesson in fine dining and on how to properly present the evenings specials.  We ordered two different pasta dishes.  The first was a spincah ravioli that was very good, but the portio was just a tad too small, it had, literally, 8 ravioli in the bowl.  The second dish was a bolognese which was average at best, and was a huge portion and look ridiculous in comparison to the first dish.  It seemed like they were trying to "cheap up" the sauce as it had large carrot chunks in it as well as celery, which is not common for that kind of dish.  The bath room requires a  card to enter because it's in the main hallway that it shared by the Hotel, the restaurant, and a Starbucks.  This is pointless since the door doesn't ever close and it is used by the public as well.  It was filthy,the ground was littered with paper, and the toilets were dirty.  I also had a glass of wine with diner, which was good, but still a cheap wine probably available at the liquor store around the corner.  We passed on dessert because of time restraints, but I can only imagine how pleasant that might have been.  

***** Saving grace: Friendly wait staff, water garnished with cucumbers, and a calm atmosphere.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
A lovely little discovery.  An excellently mellow place to sample delicious food, chat with your friends, not feel rushed, and yet somehow have always have a full glass of water without feeling like the waitstaff is hovering.  

The appetizers were fantastic - don't miss them!  Subtle flavors and a lovely presentation of the entree made it an entirely enjoyable experience.  Reasonably priced as well...
author: Taz Z.

description: My fiance, myself and our 15 year old daughter enjoyed a fabulous meal here before attending a concert at Davies Hall on 7/16/10.  This was a second trip for my fiance and I and the service was friendly and professional both times.  The New York Steak was cooked to perfection and the Gratin Potatoes were simply heavenly!  My fiance was not so impressed with the prime rib.  We feel the price is fair for the quality of the food and the service.  We'll be back!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Decided to come here before the matinee showing of Wicked on a Sunday.  I made a reservation for 12:00, but we showed up at 11:40-no problem.  We started with the Pacific trio appetizer-it was passable (the calamari was a bit too charred and the other items also had no flavor other than charred).
My husband ordered the catfish po'boy sandwich, which came with fries.  I tried it and it was very nice.  My mother-in-law had a hamburger, which came on a grilled brioche bun.    Hers also looked good.  I ordered the salmon on a bed of greens.  I was happy the portion size was not too large, as I didn't want to waste the extra and it would be awkward carrying a doggie bag to the Orpheum Theater.
My salad was okay.  The salmon was grilled and once again, the only flavor was of the charcoal grill.  Other than the bed of greens, the only other vegetables were a few pickled carrots and cucumbers on the side of the plate.
Dessert was quite good.  We ordered the chocolate decadence cake, which was moist with a nice sauce on the plate, and also the apple tart with vanilla bean gelato-mmm!.  Nice portion sizes on everything we ate except the salmon salad which was a bit small and the appetizer (which was small for 3 people).
Very good service from start to finish.  About 25 minutes after we sat down, the room filled up-probably with other theater-goers.  The waiter did a great job and we had no problem making our show in plenty of time.
I liked the ambiance of the room, too.  The carpet and drapes were a scotch plaid while the chairs were upholstered with fabric that had scenes of horses.  It was 1950's era San Francisco.  Plus, you get to watch the wonderful street show on Market St.
Overall, very pleasant-just be sure to either make a reservation or get there in plenty of time before the theater.
author: rachel l.

description:
Our reservations were at 5:45 on Saturday and we were seated promptly.  Shortly after being seated, our waiter arrived to take our bar order.  After our drinks arrived, we were served a tasty miniature stuffed apple amuse-bouch.  

The ambiance was acceptable.  We were seated near the fireplace which was nice. 

For our appetizer, we ordered 4 Oysters on the half shell.  For 2.00 each and being in San Francisco (and coming from an beach town myself), I expected a fairly delicious oyster.  What we were served were oysters no larger than a small clam.  First disappointment.  

For our entrees, I had the Cioppino and my other half had the Seared Tuna.  Both were tasty enough, but were both missing the "something special" to warrant the 26.00 price tags.  The Cioppino was basically fish and Ragu sauce and the tuna was swimming in a odd tasting brown sauce which was not really good.  

For dessert, we shared the butterscotch Creme Brule.  That was good.  It was our anniversary, so they presented the dish on a plate with the words "Happy Anniversary" inscribed in chocolate sauce.  It was a nice touch.

Overall the ambiance was nice, but the food was not worthy of the price.  Whereas nothing went horribly wrong, I probably would not return.
author: Aaron S.

description:
This place is great.  They have a new Chef who has added some really good dishes.  I had their bisque which was outstanding.  My partner got their clam chowder.  It was one of the best he has ever had.  For dinner, I had the salmon.  I would get it again too.  It was served in a unique presentation that tasted as good as it looked.

Overall, I really enjoyed my experience at this restaurant.  I loved the tiffany glass ceilings too.  I would take friends back.
author: Eric S.

description:
Prior to attending the Chinese New Year Spectacular at the Orpheum, we planned to eat at a nearby restaurant. Deciding to try the Market Street Grill, we placed our reservation over the phone, and arrived early to ensure that we had enough time before the show. We were able to be seated promptly. We managed to procure a nice table by the fireplace which was very cozy. While the decor could use an update, the food was excellent. I had the Grilled King Salmon. The presentation and flavor were fantastic. Our service was excellent and the waiter even asked if we were attending the show so that he could make sure we were done in time. 

I definitely recommend this restaurant!
author: Brian R.

description: We came here after seeing Wicked to have dessert.  The server gave my daughter a Shirley Temple which she did not want and nobody ordered and charged us $3 for it.  The clam chowder was good. The dungeness crab cake was horrible, especially for $15.  It was all filling and no crab - disappointing and gross.  We had the chocolate decadence for dessert which was delicious....we should have just gone with the dessert.  Overpriced restaurant for blah food.
author: K C.

description:
The food is superb  and when we told our waiter that we had 2 that needed to be gluten free the chef came out and talked to us personally! Major points right there! It is quite pricy, but when you're on the way to a play it's absolutely perfect! 

Thanks to the chef that's aware of the importance of gluten free for Celiac Diseased people!!
author: S L.

description:
Great food and service.  We has a large group that was attending a conference at Hotel Whitcomb....and they treated us with kindness and love.  Larry the Executive Chef came out and talked with our group on several occasions, making sure we enjoyed the food and also making vegan dishes for a few folks.  Albert the Bartender was attentive and courteous!

Really enjoy our evenings with Market Street Grill.
author: B B.

description:
Besides the interesting, and nostalgic, decor, there is little to recommend this place. The best part of our meal was a tiny appetizer which was in fact gratis -- some smoked salmon with lobster paste on a small toastie -- quite flavorful, and set up expectations which then were not met.

The "San Francisco" clam chowder is far less interesting than that you can buy at Fisherman's Wharf for 1/3 the price. The "fresh" linguine was seemingly not so "fresh" and not at all satisfying.

In short, I've walked past this place for the past 30 years, and finally decided to try it. I shant make the same mistake again.
author: Marc K.

description: I really enjoyed eating dinner at Market Street Grill.   It's a very short walk from the Orpheum Theatre.  The restaurant has white tablecloths.  The menu has good prices.  Our waiter was very helpful and very attentive to us.  My coffee cup was filled up many times and we were asked many times if things were going well.  We will definitely be back.
author: Lin D.

description: It's definitely not the greatest place in the city, but it's close to the Orpheum. The food is meh. It's kind of expensive, yet if I'm going to a musical or some other show at the Orpheum, I usually end up here for drinks before hand, mainly because it's convenient.
author: Shawna M.

description:
My wife and I had lunch at Market Street Grill before attending a matinee at the Orpheum Theatre across the street. We had an early reservation and were greeted by Chief Adam when we arrived who informed us we would receive a free starter of mussels since we had made our reservations on Open Table. 

The mussels arrived sizzling hot and were delicious. Our entrees, chicken and salmon, were wonderful! Our waiter, Kevin, provided outstanding service. The next time we are in the City, we plan on trying dinner at the Grill! We have been recommending it to all our friends.
author: David C.

description:
I have been to this restaurant 5 times now, I don't think I would be coming back so often if it was REALLY as bad as a few people on here think. The food is always wonderful, my favorite dish would have to be the Salmon Dish. It is always cooked to perfection, served very beautifully, and tastes wonderful. The artisan cheese platter is great as well. I have gotten the dish at different times of the year, and each time the Chef switches it up to give the consumer some variety.

Although I wish they would update the feel of the restaurant, I understand that the hotel is the oldest standing in San Francisco, so keeping with the old theme makes sense. (I can still wish though)

Overall, I would recommend this restaurant to anyone who is looking for a nice, quiet, pleasant meal, seated a couple blocks away from the heart of San Francisco.

For what they offer, it is truly worth it.
author: Branden J.

description:
Had dinner here before Wicked at the Orpheum. They were able to take our 14 person party, which made us quite happy. The service was scatterbrained start to finish. The food ranged from very good (cold pea soup) to average (most dishes) to disappointing (don't refer to Wild Mushrooms in a dish and then use shiitake. come on. enough people these days know the difference.)
I'd still have rated them ok, but they double charged *three people in our party*. In my case, instead of immediately disputing the charge with my credit card company, I gave the restaurant a chance to make it right. I like to keep things local and personal if possible. Unfortunately, they only made things worse. At first they transferred me to the head chef's voice mail. Head chef seemed like an odd choice for a charge dispute, but I left a short clear message. never got a call back. a week later i called again. i got quite the various stories and run around. i had to explain about 10 times that YES I WAS CHARGED TWICE. the woman i spoke to kept alternating between agreeing i had been charged twice and then suddenly not quite understanding, was i saying i had been charged twice? She had a couple of different explanations for how i had been charged twice. they had had another large group in the same room and the server had put my charge on the other table's check. at the end of the night they found the problem and 'fixed' it. Ok, so how do we fix it. Wait, she said. So, you were charged twice? She still couldn't understand what i was saying. yes. charged. twice. two charges for $140. one on the 22nd one on the 23rd. Finally she says she'll talk to the accounting department and get back to me. To her credit i did in fact get a call back which unfortunately went to my voice mail. The message said that the accounting department said i had not been charged twice, and i would have to discuss it with my bank.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Seriously, RECONSIDER! 

Pro: This restaurant is walking distance to the Orpheum Theater and parking was very convenient. 

Con: They simply cannot handle large groups and pre-show rushes. It was a 45 minutes lapse from the first person to the last person to receive their dish in our group of ten. The linguine tasted like it was left out too long (really dry) and coated with a thin milky sauce mixed with old seafood. The dish was tasteless and disgusting. I had to ask for them to take it back and bring the chicken dish. After waiting a long time, nothing tasted appetizing. I felt sick and got sick after eating here. I ask twice for everything - my sprite, utensils, crushed red peppers, black pepper, etc. 

The day after we suffered at this place, the restaurant called to inform us our bill was inappropriately mixed up with another diner. Turns out we were not charged at all for our meal there (imagine the surprise of the other group that was mixed with our bill!). This gave us an opportunity to complain about the whole experience; and to our surprise, about 50% of the entire bill was comped. Well that was nice, but honestly it wasn't worth the money even at a 50% discount.
author: Ailien P.

description: Worst dining experience ever last night.  Waiter was curt, glass of wine was served halfway through the main course in a DIRTY glass and my husbands Lobster Mac & Cheese was made with bad milk.  We spit it out with one bite.
author: Kathleen R.

description: Worst service ever.  Asian man bartender is in the wrong business for starters. We went in to sit and have a light bite to eat before a show, sat at the window table by the bar. Menus neatly placed on the table included app's, drink & a childrens menu. We waited, and waited, finally I walked up and asked the bartender about service and he told me "order here. FOOD FIRST ONLY!" I start with mac & cheese of the childrens ...he steps back and yells " no childrens food!" That was enough. We left!
author: Barbara A.

description:
nothing special.
if you want to take out the gramps, whose taste buds are just as old then heres your spot. 
in order of appearance:
bread - sourdough and raisin bread? raisin bread for dinner??
manila clams - mmmmmm...crunchy sand.
seared ahi - yes, seared means "raw" as they print on their menu but raw does not mean still fridge temp! i never had bad seared ahi... until last night.
author: Jacquelyne M.

description:
What a shame! This location is perfect to all activities in the Civic Center Area, so we decided to try it out before the Opera. 

It is painfully apparent that this once great hotel & restaurant survives on unsuspecting tourists. We started with the cheese plate, and while the selection was minimal is was made even less deireable by the fact that it was ice cold, clearly having just been plucked from a walk-in. 

For our entree selection, the salmon on was undercooked and caused some stomach distress (although it was recommended by the staff) and the bolognese sauce was burnt and the spaghetti was over cooked. 

In addition, the staff also seemed overwhelmed by the sheer number of tourists in large groups.

With all of the amazing restaurants in the area, best to stay away and hope for a better chef!
author: Julie M.

description: Mediocre at best.  :(  Let's put it this way:  the bread was the best part of the meal.  I ordered the shellfish linguine and my mom got the salmon.  Her meal arrived with totally undercooked fish!  yuck.  My pasta was good, but nothing that deserved much excitement or the $21 price tag.  Oh well, I guess it was the only half-way decent place that close to the Orpheum.  Good thing Wicked was awesome and totally made up for our boring meal.
author: Wendy V.

description: When we arrived, they asked if we were there for the show at the Orpheum that evening and were very considerate of the fact that we hadn't left a lot of time for dinner, and provided quick service. The food was definitely on the pricey side but the atmosphere was pleasing, and the food had such a nice presenation.  I thought the caesar salad and crab cake were good though nothing special (my friend disagreed - she found the cheese on the caesar salad to be particularly good). but my chicken alla scallopini was delicious!  Very close to 5 stars in my book.
author: Jennifer K.

description: Mediocre all around.  It's very close to the opera house and theaters, so that is worthy of a star, but it's just a mediocre experience.  Our food was unremarkable - I actually don't remember any details about it and we were there just a few nights ago.  Service was also a bit slow - I had to remind them about a glass of wine I ordered and it took so long for our waiter to return after giving us the dessert menus, we decided against ordering.  I suppose it's a decent option for pre-theater dining, but I wasn't really impressed.
author: Michelle C.

description: I was here twice in my life.  Both times were while waiting for Wicked at the Orpheum to open.  This right across the intersection from Orpheum and although it gets crowded and the wait can be long, here is the secret.  Sit at the Bar.  Order from the Bar.  Let the bartender know that tip and timelyness will go hand in hand.  I got my food in five minutes while most of the tables who were already there were not even giving orders yet.  The food was OK but slightly expensive even considering the area.  I had a hamburger and frys (no surprise) and it was OK.  Not for the money, but hey, it's location in this case.  The bartender gets five stars, the place gets three.
author: John P.

description: 6 months later and my credit card was finally able to confirm my refund.  Like I said before, if you must dine here, PAY W/ CASH!
author: Amy L.

description: This restaurant has a great location for those attending a show at the Orpheum as it's just across the street.  The decor is attractive and very much on the fancy side of things.  The wait staff was very helpful and friendly despite mis-hearing one of our orders and bringing the prime rib instead of the ribs, they were apologetic and quick to bring the correct dish.  Overall the food was very good if a bit pricey.  The Apple walnut salad was very fresh and light and the ribs had a great flavor too them with just enough vegetable and potato fingers on the side.  Overall, a good choice for a fancy night out.
author: Kevin D.

description:
I was very, very pleasantly surprised with this place. I had never even heard of it but wanted to try a Dine About Town before seeing Hairspray at the Orpheum and saw this restaurant was across the street. It's located in a hotel and let me tell you, this place has the most magnificent dining chairs I've ever seen. Western scenery tapestry, A-MAZE-ING. I spent most of dinner trying to figure out how to fit a chair into my purse and sneak it out of the restaurant. I think it would make a pretty amazing work chair.
The food was actually really good. We started with the fritto misto, fried calamari and veggies with this spicy sriracha aioli. This dish really had some kick to it. I then had the chowder which was meh, really need a lot of salt and it had an almost gluey taste. My bouillabaisse was tasty and the portion was generous, I couldn't even finish it, I had a bite of my friend's chicken and noodles and boy were those noodles good. Comfort food at it's best. Finished up with a boozy Jack Daniel's bread pudding. All in all a great little find. I will definitely keep this place in mind anytime I'm seeing a show at the Orpheum.
author: Cathy T.

description: An elegant place to dine especially if you are in the area waiting to watch a play. It was a nice place with live music from a man on the piano. Felt like walking into nordstrom for a minute. The quality of food is great, however, the portion is not. If you are looking for quality food, at an expensive rate, this is not a bad place to try out. Its a little more on the upscale side to entertain those who like this kind of dining experience. Cheers.
author: Chris D.

description: Overpriced and poor service.  9 dollars for a tiny green salad that's not on the menu so I didn't realize until the bill came that it was $9.00.  The ravioli I had was delicious but service and price don't overway that.  The menu outside the restaurant said they featured Halibut and when I got inside Halibut was no longer on the menu. Dissapointing. I was STUCK going here because I was going to the Orpheum across the street and I'm bummed that I spent soo much money in a mediocre venue.
author: Katie K.

description:
I had no preconceived expectations (first time @ Market Street Grill in the Hotel Whitcom) - and found this to be a delightful place to eat before the afternoon performance of Wicked!  

Our party of 8 was seated next to the fireplace, perfect due to the rare cold wet sporadically rainy weather that day .  Service was terrific; attentive without being oppressive, the food very good; lunch fare was fresh and delicious.  Everyone seemed to enjoy their meal - I thought my portion size was just right.

We were also celebrating a birthday, and the restaurant accommodated our cake brought in for the occasion without a hitch.

It was also a very nice touch to receive a kind word from the Chef - a lovely gesture amidst the busy surroundings.   

I'm looking forward to making the Market Street Grill the restaurant of choice prior to attending performances at the Orpheum.  Another reviewer commented on parking being much more reasonably priced at the Whitcom too.
author: Ms. H.

description:
This was unquestionably the worst overall experience I've had with a restaurant. I cannot warn you strongly enough against dining here.

We made a reservation for a large party with 14 people, and we were put in a back room which was extremely cold. The service was extremely slow: our server would sometimes disappear for over 20 minutes, and the food was mediocre and not worth the price. 

On top of being abandoned in a freezing room, my wife's debit card was double charged. After arguing back and forth with them for a week about it, they finally told us to talk to our bank about it. We filed a report with the bank, and the bank complained about the restaurant to us! Even though MSG could only produce one credit card slip for our bank, they *still* wouldn't take the charge off. Our only recourse was for our bank to declare FRAUD, which means that my wife had to get a new debit card with a different number and change that number everywhere she has bills on autopay.

I'm shocked that this place is still in business. Avoid it at all costs.
author: john s.

description: I don't think they ever charge for dessert at this place. We heard the pianist play "Happy Birthday" at least seven times as wait staff subtly brought candle-clad plates of delicacies to tables all around us. After our own scrumptious meal (ample portions of steak and charmingly presented risotto-stuffed quail), we were surprised by a heavenly complementary portion of cheescake. No song, but the plate did say "happy anniversary" in chocolate. Very convenient to the Orpheum and the staff is cognizant of your time constraints and makes sure you don't miss the curtain!
author: Edith S.

description: What a surprise!  Went to Phantom after New Year (1/3/09).We went with the recommended restaurants near Orpheum, on their site.  Delicious food and friendly service.  Holiday decor was still in full swing which was nice, and the holiday menu was delicious.  Quail dish was very tiny for the price but tasty and beautifully presented.  Made a reservation and all went well with seating.  Service was quick (a little too quick) but that's what most customers will be looking for given the location.
author: Michelle B.

description:
food: 3.75
service: 5
atmosphere: 4

it was a pretty quiet night at the grill so the very large party of us were attended to attentively without feeling bothered (well.. almost. i did run out of water there at the end). the waitstaff was textbook --i love it !-- subtle (but present), fast (but not hurried), kind (but not meddlesome), and professional (but not unfriendly). perfect!

the food was ok. nothing spectacular, above avg. and reasonably priced (~$22/plate). 

i could see this joint going either way depending on the crowd-- "swanky" hotel restaurant (but not Clift-pretentious, and still reasonably priced!) or quiet under-the-radar good for generic first date dinner spot.
author: Miss C.

description: I had the pleasure of eating here on my visit to San Francisco in October. I would have written this sooner but I have been having trouble with my yelp account. This place was amazing. i went with a group of friends and had one of the best meals I've had since I moved to California 3 years ago. The grilled king salmon is perfect, the flavors are amazing. This is definitely a must try if are in San Francisco. Kudos to you, Chef Adam. I look forward to future visits to your restaurant whenever I am in the area.
author: Carlos A.

description: The place was very accommodating after we got stuck in traffic and showed up late.  The decor is mid-western hotel kitsch.  The service was given with excellent attitude, but not promptly (but we weren't in a hurry, so didn't mind.)  The food was very good, with an interesting selection (a great Cesar salad, for instance.)  The wine list was very nice.  The desserts were great!  The parking was convenient (around back) and the location (across from the Orpheum where we saw Avenue Q (awesome)) is excellent.  I just wouldn't make a special trip to eat here, but if you are going to the theater, I don't think you can do any better.
author: mike r.

description:
We stumbled upon Market Street Grill while in search for a place to have dinner before the Eddie Izzard show at the Orpheum. We weren't sure what to expect, but felt welcomed by the cozy atmosphere and the wonderful wait staff (especially the charming Yolanda, who was attentive yet unobtrusive). 
     It took a while to decide what to have since everything on the menu sounded awesome (we especially appreciated the use of local produce), but nothing prepared us for being absolutely blown away by the amazing dishes. 
     I had the clam chowder, which was the best I've ever had (perfect balance of ingredients, great consistency, and almost sweet). The roasted beet salad made me swoon... the presentation was gorgeous, and the combination of the beets with the fromage blanc and caramelized nuts, along with the crisp "green" taste of the watercress... perfection. Then came the main course of short ribs. Who needed a knife?? The meat was so tender it melted in my mouth, and the sour cherry gastrique was the perfect compliment. And the wine-soaked cauliflower!! Amazing. I joked, "Would it be rude if I licked my plate?", but secretly I really wanted to!
     I love food, and Chef Jones' is pure artistry. I would have gone to the kitchen to hug him had my friends not been pulling me out the door to get to the show. It was one of the best meals I've had in a long time, and I look forward to visiting again and trying more of his works of art.
author: J. A.

description:
This was a great place to eat at especially right before a show at the Orpheum Theater they were used to servicing guests that have the dinner then show schedule to stick to and it was literally right across the street.
the service was very speedy and the food was pretty good salads were huge and the food portions were more than enough. Everything tasted great. The restroom situation was a little awkward  and not nice at all but over all that was the only complaint we had.
author: Jason O.

description: What I love about this restaurant is that it supports sustainable, locally and organically grown, hormone-free products. I know they get a lot of their food from Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market and it shows. The food is fresh and delicious. I had a lobster omelete off the menu and it was great. They have great large windows so the morning light shined through - it was a great breakfast :)
author: Lauren M.

description: Overpriced for what it is. Food was only passable, at best. But to watch the waiter's reaction to other diners who weren't availaing of wine to push up the check or had children in their company, one would think they were depriving him of his livlihood AND somehow lowering the tone. My impression before I booked this spot (I should have done better research!) was of a restauarant that served American classics in faded yet still plush surroundings...wrong on both counts. Pulling out your chair and placing your napkin for you does not high end make. Yet despite all of the foregoing, the place was crowded. Largely, I imagine, as a result of its proximity to the theatre. The 'quality' of the food or service certainly couldn't account for the crowds.
author: Jules P.

description:
This is my second visit to the Market Street Grill and I enjoyed it this time as much if not more than my first time. The service is impeccable. We were greeted very warmly by the hostess and made to feel very welcome and very special. Our waiter was attentive in a very gracious way. 

The food was excellent! The heirloom tomato gazpacho was refreshing and the delicate flavors of the tomatoes was wonderful. I could have eaten another bowl. The crab cake appetizer was plentiful and had a wonderful kick to it. The grilled salmon we had was moist and melted in our mouths. I especially enjoyed the berry parfait with lavender pastry cream. It was light and perfect for a summer evening. The light taste of lavender was a wonderful taste I had never experienced before.

The Market Street Grill is a wonderful restaurant with high quality service and high quality food. It is a wonderful place to go for a special dinner or a special night out before the symphony or a show. I highly recommend it. You will not be disappointed!
author: Rochelle N.

description: I went to Wicked saturday night, and we wanted to eat at a place in walking distance and found this restaurant. The wait wasn't too long. They were aware of everyone there to see wicked and said we will get seated and served quickly. So that was very cool. I decided to get the $16 spanish ravioli . I'm already thinking i better eat good because i don't want to have to bring a container with leftovers in the theater. Well there was no need for any of that. The portion was so small. My friend and I were cracking up looking at my meal. I mean there was about 4 small spinach ravilois with a bit of lettuce on type (seems like to hide the portion). I was finished in a matter of 2 minutes. I mean thats great as a side for $5. But $16!!!!!! plus tip. Really huge rip off. I'm not quite sure on the portions of other meals on the menu. But going forward I would only recommend this place for the bar. The drinks were good and the bartender was fast. But as far as the dinner portion it is way too pricy for a meal. You can eat way better for less at other places.
author: S R.

description: I have been here about 30 times. What a hidden gem! The chef here used to work at Kuleto's. I have had everything on the menu and it is all great. The seasoned fries are awesome. The breads they serve are awesome. They are not the cheapest place around, but the food is great, the service is ALWAYS great, and the atmosphere and appointments are great. This place harks back to the days when all of the best restaurants were in hotels. Prime rib here is awesome, and if you have the burger for lunch you will not eat until the next day because it is sooooo big. French Onion with Gruyere cheese is the best. House red wine is tasty too!
author: Eddie L.

description:
Early this summer, my designer-historian husband made reservations for the children and me at the Hotel Whitcomb.  I was a little wary of the Market Grill - I thought that it might be too posh for the kids.  One night, after a good chilly prowl through the city, I treated the children to dinner at the Grill.  It was divine.  The children's menu was simple but really, really good, and I gave myself an unbridled go at the menu, accompanied by some great wine.  As my family was treated like royalty and my kids rose to the occasion with their best party manners, I was able to enjoy my delicious food in embracing golden candle light.The whole evening was wonderful.  I wouldn't have changed a thing. Just last week the kids referred to the dinner - "you know when you have a big scoop of ice-cream and you eat it and it's over, and when you have something really, really good you think about it for a long time?..."
Thanks for the great ice-cream and for providing the delectable memories.
author: M. B.

description: I've gone there for a beer and now for lunch yesterday.  No happy hour for drinks and the lunch did not justify the price.  In fact, I get the heeby jeebies just thinking about the $11 french dip sandwich I ordered and all the fat I picked out of it to make it somewhat edible.  I won't be going back anytime soon.
author: Josh E.

description: I work on 1275 Market and went next door to have lunch at the Market St. Grill one day.  I had no idea what to expect.  I mean I walk pass the place everyday on my way to BART.  And in passing I always glanced through the tinted windows seeing people laughing and dining, just having a good ole time. Well one day, I was invited to try the place for lunch.  I was excited and really didn't know what kind of experience I would have.  I walked into a very elegant atmosphere and was greeted by a very courteous staff.  I was seated and greeted by the Chef, Adam Jones.  I knew him from the Franciscan Restaurant at the Wharf.  He made an awesome menu with a dizzying array of seafood prepared the San Francisco way.  I sampled this fried salmon pâté wonton which produced a medley of tastes with good sensations.  My palate had a party.  The crispness of the wonton with the smooth creaminess of the salmon pâté was perfect.  I then ordered the Frito Misto.  A delicious appetizer of fried seafood and vegetables with a sauce that some kick to it.  After chowing down on the appetizer, I got the main course, seared salmon.  It was perfect, with shiitake mushrooms and this oyster sauce that melted in your mouth.  The salmon was cooked perfect, firm and tender in the inside.  I enjoyed my meal there and realized that I've been missing out on some fantastic dishes.  I can't wait to get back in there with a couple of my co-workers and enjoy another meal!
author: ron c.

description: An absolutely horrible dining experience, ordered the Boulebaise which was the equivalent of a cup of thin soup with some clams, mussels and potatoes served in an oversized bowl with toasted flat sliced sourdough bread.  The chef should be embarrased serving something like this or perhaps he is still laughing.
author: Ron P.

description: As others have said, the dining room doesn't currently suit the type of restaurant it is, and the food that's served, but apparently there is plan to update it soon. Regardless of the decor, the experience was wonderful! The Hostess Cassandra and our waiter Sol were not only talented and efficient, they were so fun! They made our meal experience very entertaining! And then the food came. Wow! Every person in our group of 6 raved about their meal. I had the seared Halibut with shredded carrots and ginger and mashed potatoes. I savored every bite! This isn't a cheap restaurant but it was well worth the price! I would definitely go again and will recommend it to all my friends.
author: Tara B.

description: Arriving for a 6:30 reservation we were shown to a 2 top in a corner next to a partition wall where I was to sit looking at another  wall and the door into the kitchen. After asking to be moved to one of many vacant tables, we were shown to a table in the middle of the dining room. We were told the table by the window was "reserved" and we could not sit there. It remained empty until just before 8 PM when we left. They were all out of quail and osso buco by 6:40 PM. We had to request bread be brought to the table. The seared ahi tuna was ice cold and obviously straight out of the refrigerator. The grilled salmon was OK.  My bread plate was dirty and had to be returned. The Thai tomatoe bisque soup tasted like pureed tomatoes straight out of the can. The clam chowder was OK. The seafood pasta that the manager insisted bringing to the table to make up for the very refrigerated (apparently after it was seared) ahi was bland, and loaded up with undercooked frozen shrimp and scallops. On the positive side, no-one got sick. The server and manager were both appropriately apologetic. They were apologizing to a lot more tables than ours!  They did not charge for the ahi. My companion and I had some doubts whether the Grey Goose Martinis really were Grey Goose. We made it to the Orpheum on time for the show. Wish they served hamburgers and Cobb salads, something their kitchen can realistically turn out. I just kept thinking what a great venue for an episode of Kitchen Nightmares with Gordon Ramsey. We will not be back.
author: Bob J.
